results.description:
Visas for Startups: H-1B and Alternatives

In this workshop, Lisa Eisenberg, Esq., an experienced immigration attorney working primarily with technology startups, will discuss H-1B and other visa options for foreign startup founders and employees.  We will talk about best practices in filing H-1B petitions for small, recently formed companies. We will also discuss the lesser-known option of O-1 visa - an ideal solution for many startup founders and employees who satisfy the regulatory criteria. Lisa will share her experience in successfully obtaining this coveted visa for entrepreneurs, software developers, web designers, UX designers and other tech professionals.  She will also provide an overview of other visas for work and training (L-1, E, J-1, etc.) Lastly, we will cover President Obama’s executive actions aimed to benefit foreign-owned startups and their founders, including the proposed “significant public benefit” parole program for entrepreneurs. 

Agenda:

8:15 a.m. - 8:45 am 
Registration check-in & continental breakfast 

8:45 a.m. – 9:30 a.m. 
Presentation

9:30 am - 10 am

Q&A

About the speaker: 


Lisa Eisenberg, Esq. is the Founder and Principal of Eisenberg Law Firm PLLC, an immigration law firm specializing in visa solutions for tech startups and founders. The firm’s narrow focus and specialized expertise help overcome many challenges faced by startups in the immigration process.

Foreign entrepreneurs often have a difficult time getting a work visa in the U.S. because our country does not offer a “startup visa” or any other option well-suited for startup founders.  This prevents many founders from legally working in the U.S., effectively managing their businesses, or obtaining funding.  

Eisenberg Law Firm PLLC has the experience to utilize existing work visas for the unique needs of tech startup founders in technology and other fields. The firm also assists small and mid-size U.S. tech companies seeking H-1B, L-1, O-1 and other work visas for foreign professionals.
results.name: Visas for Startups: H-1B and Alternatives Presented by Lisa Eisenberg, Esq

results.description:
For coworking space, it's first come first served. You'll want to get there early to find a desk before it fills up. The space is available from 10am to 6pm. If you are planning on attending, you'll need to do the following things:

• Register at the AWS Pop-up Loft Space - https://aws.amazon.com/start-ups/loft/ny-loft/

• Once you are registered you can pick up a badge and attend any of the co-working meetups.

• Let us know you are going by signing up for the event on meetup. This also lets other people in the group know who is going to be there too.

• Remember to check the Pop-up Loft website to make sure it is open. We'll do out best to cancel meetups on holidays and days the space won't be available but you should also double check before coming out.

• While there are snacks and drinks at the space, lunch is not provided. There are a number of restaurants, delis and other places to get food in the area so plan accordingly

• These daily coworking events are self run. A co-organizer will not always be at the event. These events are designed to give game developers a free space to work so you'll basically be left alone at the space to do you own thing. We suggest reaching out to other attending through the comments to sit together or meet up at a specific time in the space.

Last thing, two times a month we'll have a dedicated space for you to come out and work as well as listen to talks and get help from myself and others in the community. Those will be different events you'll need to register for which are separate from the daily co-working space.
results.name: Indie Coworking Space

While existing crime drivers continue to plague organizations across the globe, names like CoreBot, Shifu, and Sphinx are all are new banking Trojans that emerged in 2015, marking relentless progress and escalation in the cybercrime arena that stretched over the entire year.

Analog and classic cameras can be a great inexpensive way to add variety to your portrait, fashion and other photo work. Daniel Norton will show several types of cameras, films and instant emulsions, as well as advanced techniques like paper negatives that will set your creativity free.

During the session we will create portraits using several different types of cameras and emulsions, as well as demonstrate some contact printing techniques. This is a hands-on demo, come try out some cool cameras or have your portrait made. We will introduce you to cameras with full manual control, as well as cover techniques to help you control and get better results from those cameras that are fully automatic.

LEARN: How to incorporate instant film photography into your portrait shoots.

TRY: Cameras that allow manual control and work with your current flash and continuous lighting kits.

LEARN: How to make emulsion lifts and create image transfers.

LEARN: How to shoot and process Paper Negatives.

There will be 3 unique sessions. Come for one or all. Sessions start at 12pm, 2pm and 4pm

results.description:
http://cdn2.hubspot.net/hub/241939/hubfs/BEE/BROOKINGS_logo.jpg?t=1452287965539&width=469

Beyond bitcoin: The future of blockchain and disruptive financial technologies 

HOSTED BY:

The Hutchins Center on Fiscal and Monetary Policy

To Register for this remarkable event you must click HERE.

When: Thursday, January 14, 2016, 1:15  – 3:00 PM EST 

What: 

Bitcoin, the digital currency, has attracted both attention and controversy. But the most potent innovation is not the currency itself. Rather, it’s the technology that undergirds bitcoin, the distributed-ledger technology known as the blockchain that allows payments to flow through an economy in an entirely decentralized way—without banks or other intermediaries. This infant technology could change the financial system; think the Internet before browsers. It could reduce the cost and increase in the speed and accuracy of financial transactions; it could truly disrupt the banking business. Or it could fizzle. But already it is raising a host of policy questions – about financial stability, consumer protection, choking off terrorists' finances, and tensions between established and upstart financial institutions and between regulatory agencies.

On January 14, the Hutchins Center on Fiscal and Monetary Policy at Brookings will explore the future of distributed ledger technology, paying special attention to the innovation’s impact on financial services and policymaking. Hutchins Center director David Wessel will convene leading industry and policy experts for a panel discussion. After the session, panelists will take audience questions.

You can join the conversation and tweet questions for the panelists at #BeyondBitcoin.

To Register for this remarkable event you must click HERE. 

Personal Note: 

We are very fortunate to have the opportunity to participate in this event with such an elite institution and distinguished panel. Big thank you to Camilo M. Ramírez of Brookings.

David Wessel

results.description:
THE SALE IS FINALLY HERE!

The Toyota Club in the Metlife Stadium will be transformed into the largest ski & snowboard shop on the east coast, where you'll find over 30,000 sq. ft. packed with amazing deals of up to 80% off Skis, Snowboards, Outerwear, Winter Apparel & Accessories, Partner Resort Lift Ticket and Lodging specials and a Free Lift Ticket to Windham Mountain or Mountain Creek with the purchase of every Ski or Snowboard


Just like when attending ski films, there are also a lot of free swag to be had including lift tickets, raffles for trips, drinks and other items.  It is a very popular sale, so you will have to deal with crowds, but enjoy very good prices.  If you are a beginner skier or snowboarder, you could probably pick up everything you need right here!


Transportation:

• If driving, there is free parking in Lot F or G.  See here for details

• From NYC there is a free shuttle from Union Square.  See here for details

Getting Inside:

The specific location of the sale is not actually in Metlife stadium, but in the Toyota Club.  The Club is near the parking areas, (Lots F or G). 


Shopping Tips:

Go as early as possible as all the merchandise is on display and for popular items you will want get the deepest discounts.  Not everything sells though, so don't worry if you can't make it on the first day. 


Go with a friend.  As soon as you both get inside, one of you go to the end of the line.  Then take turns shopping.  Last year I did not heed my own advice and waited over an hour, after all my shopping was done!

Dressing Tips:

If you are going early on the first day, be prepared for waiting outside, so dress warmly.  Also wear clothing that can breathe as it may also get very warm inside with so many shoppers. 
Wear comfortable footwear as you will be on your feet the entire time.  Wear ski socks if you plan to try on ski and snowboard boots.

results.description:
Spinnaker is an open source, multi-cloud continuous delivery platform for releasing software changes with high velocity and confidence. Continuous delivery in practice allows organizations to release software quickly and reliably. It integrates software build, test and release processes by automating workflows that push software changes forward.

Netflix open sourced Spinnaker in November, after close collaborative effort with Google, Pivotal and Microsoft. Come hear from the engineering team from Google - get an introduction to Spinnaker, talk about how continuous integration works in practice, and ask questions about implementation specifics.

Speakers:

Rick Buskens, Engineering Manager, Spinnaker, Google

Rick Buskens is an engineering manager in the Developer Infrastructure group at Google, where he and his team believe in providing a great developer experience for cloud platform users, and in leveraging and contributing to open source software to deliver on this experience.


Rick will discuss the motivations behind continuous delivery, assess current best practices and opportunities, and discuss how Spinnaker uniquely fills various limitations by walking through its constructs.


Drew Michel, Site Reliability Engineer, Spotify

Drew Michel is a Site Reliability Engineer at Spotify focusing on providing developers with a self-service platform for managing capacity on bare-metal and public clouds.

Dave Stenglein, SVP of Architecture, Kenzan

Dave Stenglein is SVP of Architecture and Engineering at Kenzan where he is focused on building cloud platform solutions for clients that consist of devops tooling combined with 12 factor apps. Dave is a technology professional (sysadmin, developer, devops) with over 20 years experience and is driven to produce systems with robust, scalable, and secure architectures. Kenzan has helped with Spinnaker focusing on bootstrapping and ease of use.

Matt Duftler, Technical Lead, Spinnaker, Google

Matt Duftler is a Senior Software Engineer in the Developer Infrastructure group at Google where he has been leading Google's efforts on Spinnaker since 2014. Matt also implemented the Google Cloud Platform plugin for Cloudera Director. Prior to Google, Matt spent many years at IBM Research working on topics ranging from Scripting and Component-Oriented Programming Languages, to Web Services, to Business Process Intelligence and workflow languages/engines.

Agenda:

5:30 - 6:00 pm: Attendees Registration / Networking

6:00 - 6:15 pm: Brittney Coulson - Google Cloud Platform Overview

6:15 - 6:45 pm: Rick Buskens - Spinnaker and Continuous Delivery

6:45 - 7:15pm: Drew Michel - Continuous Delivery and Spinnaker at Spotify

7:15 - 7:45pm: Dave Stenglein - Continuous Delivery best practices

7:45 - 8:30pm: Matt Duftler - Spinnaker demo

8:30 pm+: Q&A, Networking and Goodnight

Please visit http://spinnaker.io/ for more info on Spinnaker.

results.description:
Free admission!

Join us for a wine and cheese reception, followed by a sign language-interpreted private gallery talk focusing on one of MoMA's special exhibitions.

This event will be about the Picasso sculpture exhibition:

Picasso Sculpture is a sweeping survey of Pablo Picasso’s innovative and influential work in three dimensions. This will be the first such museum exhibition in the United States in nearly half a century.

Over the course of his long career, Picasso devoted himself to sculpture wholeheartedly, if episodically, using both traditional and unconventional materials and techniques. Unlike painting, in which he was formally trained and through which he made his living, sculpture occupied a uniquely personal and experimental status for Picasso. He approached the medium with the freedom of a self-taught artist, ready to break all the rules. This attitude led him to develop a deep fondness for his sculptures, to which the many photographs of his studios and homes bear witness. Treating them almost as members of his household, he cherished the sculptures' company and enjoyed re-creating them in a variety of materials and situations. Picasso kept the majority in his private possession during his lifetime. It was only in 1966, through the large Paris retrospective Hommage à Picasso, that the public became fully aware of this side of his work. Following that exhibition, in 1967 The Museum of Modern Art organized The Sculpture of Picasso, which until now was the first and only exhibition on this continent to display a large number of the artist’s sculptures.

Picasso Sculpture focuses on the artist’s lifelong work with sculpture, with a particular focus on his use of materials and processes. The exhibition, which features more than 100 sculptures, complemented by selected works on paper and photographs, aims to advance the understanding of what sculpture was for Picasso, and of how he revolutionized its history through a lifelong commitment to constant reinvention. The exhibition is organized in chapters corresponding to the distinct periods during which Picasso devoted himself to sculpture, each time exploring with fresh intensity the modern possibilities of this ancient art form.

Taken from the MoMA website

Event description: http://www.moma.org/visit/calendar/events/24899

Exhibition description: http://www.moma.org/visit/calendar/exhibitions/1559

results.description:
Please join us for a fireside chat with Kevin Lee, CEO at Didit.com on Thursday, January 14th from 6 - 8pm.

Kevin Lee - Didit CEO & Co-Founder, has been an acknowledged Search Engine Marketing expert since 1995. Kevin’s years of SEM expertise provide the foundation for Didit’s proprietary Maestro search campaign technology. Didit’s unparalleled results and client growth have earned Didit recognition, not only among marketers, but also as part of the Inc 500 (#137) in 2007, as well as the #12 position on Deloitte’s Fast 500. 

Kevin’s “Paid Search Strategies” column for ClickZ is read by thousands, and his book, “The Eyes Have It: How to Market in an Age of Divergent Consumers, Media Chaos, and Advertising Anarchy” has been widely praised.

A founding board member of SEMPO, and its first elected Chairman; Kevin is also active on DMA and IAB Committees. The Wall Street Journal, Business Week, The New York Times, Bloomberg, CNET, USA Today, San Jose Mercury News and other press, quote Kevin regularly. Kevin lectures at leading industry conferences plus universities including NYU, Columbia, Fordham, and Pace.

Kevin earned his MBA from Yale School of Management in 1992, and lives in Manhattan with his wife (a New York Psychologist) and daughter. More recently, Kevin was recognized as an Ernst & Young Entrepreneur Of The Year® 2008 Award Finalist in New York.

Fireside chat format:


• 6:00 - 6:30 pm: Open Networking

• 6:30 - 7:15 pm: Fireside Chat using a Q&A approach, (35mins between speaker and organizer, and 10mins between speaker and audience)

• 7:15 - 8:00 pm: Open Networking

Contribution - $5 with your RSVP online.

Please RSVP by 4 pm Thursday, January 14th. No walk-ins will be allowed!

Wine and snacks will be served.  Can't wait to see you there!

Have a great idea for a guest speaker?  Please let us know!

results.description:
REGISTER at www.javasig.com


"Java Lambdas - What the Func?!" - Pratik Patel
Lambdas in Java 8 are here. They are a critical part of Java now.  You need to know how to use them and why you need to use them.  In this session, we’ll do some live coding and compare how Lambdas in Java 8 compare to other programming languages to give you some insights on developing with Lambdas.

"Java Performance: Biggest Mistakes" - Andreas Grabner

Most performance problems in Java Applications under load don't require a large load test to find out where the issues are. The top problems in the last year are all around architectural issues such as excessive database access, allocating too many objects, bad connection pool handling or badly deployed and configured frameworks. In this session I show you several real life use cases, the metrics to look at and how to capture these metrics with your unit and integration tests. We are going to use free available tools such as JMeter, JUnit, Dynatrace, ... to get this accomplished.

REGISTER at www.javasig.com  (DO NOT REGISTER VIA MEETUP)

results.name: Java Lambdas - What the Func?! -and- Java Performance: Biggest Mistakes

This talented brother has fallen on hard times, and as most people, would prefer to stand strong on their on two feet and take care of themselves, however, as most of you  may or may not know, alot of recording artist don't have medical coverage or benefits.  The Colonel is very ill with no permanent  place of his own to live at this time and limited financial resources. Those of us who have listened to his awesome music and know of his plight, have banned together to try and help him through this rough patch.

Housemusic Promoter, Producer and iconic dee jay Don Welch of the Underground Network along with myself and others,  are calling on all his fans worldwide to join in helping us in this mission to raise enough money to get him  consistent housing, access to wrap around social services as well as to help give his finances a boast, so that he can get back on track to sustaining himself with the assistance of a credible accounting firm we have identified that is willing to donate some of their services!!!

results.description:
You can also buy tickets through eventbrite here: http://bit.ly/1lQ2UGt

Early bird registration: Register before January 1st and pay only $20!

What would you like to achieve in the new year 2016?


It could be anything - doubling your sales, becoming fit, getting out of consumer debt, mastering a marketing tool, learn public speaking, or having a better relationship.

The journey to achievement begins with scientific goal setting.With a clear objective and a strategic plan, every goal can become a reality. Once you successfully apply the principles to one area of your life you can use them in all the other areas. In essence, this puts you on an upward spiral of success.

Please join us in this fun and exciting evening of learning and networking with like minded people who are as committed to success as you are.

In this hands on workshop you will:

• Set goals using five keys that dramatically increase the odds of success.

• Create a strategy and a detailed plan of action.

• Learn how to remain focused on a goal when faced with distractions and competing goals.

• Learn how to maximize your most important resource for achievement - self control.

• Design an effective tracking system.

• Work with an accountability group.

• Use power tools such as leverage, Kaizen, and precommitment.

• Get the seminar notes for review.


We will follow a structured format :

6:00-6:15pm - Registration

6:15-8:00pm - Workshop

8:00-8:15pm - Questions

Cost: It is only $30 prepaid, or $40 cash/door

Early bird registration: Register before January 1st and pay only $20

About the speaker: Dr. Kool holds a PhD in Quantum Physics. His gift lies at using cutting edge research from neuroscience, behavioral economics, psychology, and management to help individuals and organizations achieve long term performance gains.

What people are saying about our past goal setting event:

"I felt like this meetup helped me get in touch with myself and with other people. Dr. Kool encouraged me with his analogies. I feel motivated to take some steps to improve myself and the way I'm doing things. It was great to meet other people from similar & different industries and to network a bit."- Jessica Duran

"Excellent meetup. Dr Kool is an excellent business consultant and the environment is perfect for constructive criticism. This was easily the best meetup event that I have ever attended. I'll definitely attend again next month!"- Vinay Raval

"Wonderful goal setting advice. I couldn't wait to start creating some new goals and refocusing on some old ones. Good group of people from a variety of industries. Great networking."-Holly Surgue

"Everything about this event was a success. A great, motivated, friendly group of people, an excellent presentation by Dr. Kool, enough structure to help everyone connect in the best possible way - can't wait for the next one!"-Emma Larkins

"Great to meet everyone and I enjoyed the seminar by Dr. Kool. It was very well organized and I liked the structure that other networking meetups don't have."-Irene Grassi Osborne

results.description:
Time to enjoy the Thursday evening hikes in the dark.

Bring your headlamps as we'll be hiking in the dark  for this hike.

[masked], [masked] are the exact GPS Coordinates for the trail head.  The lower lot is technically right across the street from 64 Skyline Drive address.

5 - 7 ish miles, with about a 900 ft elevation gain

We will meet at the LOWER lot of skyline drive in Oakland at 6pm on Thursday evening. This will be approximately a 2 - 3 hour hike.

We will take the blue trail to Ramapo Lake and left on Lake Shore Drive Carriage Road around the lake to a brief meetup with the Cannonball trail but headed to orange.  Once on orange we will cross over the pipeline and head to overlook view points and then follow the orange on a beautiful loop back to the pipeline.  We'll then head up the pipeline to the top and make a right on the white trail that leads us to some nice views of a perhaps fading sunset and NYC skyline.


We will walk through the Van Slyke Castle. http://theoaklandjournal.com/oaklandnj/hike-into-history/">http://theoaklandjournal.com/oaklandnj/hike-into-history/</a>;  and descend down most likely we'll take the white back to lake shore road with a probable detour through an unmarked shortcut.  Once on lake shore we can run, jog or walk back to the dam where we'll get some pics and hang out a bit before descending blue back to the parking lot.


This route may change from week to week depending on group so please have a map or gps.

http://www.state.nj.us/dep/parksandforests/parks/maps/NYNJTC_NJParkMaps-RamapoMtn_2015-85x11.pdf"></a>" class="linkified">http://www.state.nj.us/dep/parksandforests/parks/maps/NYNJTC_NJParkMaps-RamapoMtn_2015-85x11.pdf;

Bring headlamps, maps and water. Have fun!

--------------------------------------------------------------

If you join us for a hike (or any other event), please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury or mishap. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. You are responsible to research the event, know the area, and bring the proper gear. 

The Hudson Valley Hikers Club does not provide liability insurance for the protection of individuals who may participate in any of the events planned by the Organizer or Assistant Organizers. 

This release extends and applies to, and also covers and includes, all unknown, unforeseen, unanticipated and unsuspected injuries, damages, loss and liability. 

Your attendance on a hike signifies that you have read and accept the terms of this liability waiver. By signing up for this group or event you understand that you are attending all events AT YOUR OWN RISK. Organizers and Assistant Organizers of this group are just that, we organize the events and hike together as friends. There are no leaders on these hikes, you are your own leader- This is YOUR hike.

results.description:
I knit as a hobby, but I weave as a profession, so it only makes sense that I'd share that skill, too. This month I am including weaving in the mix alongside the DIY Blog Tour that I am spearheading for American Tapestry Alliance (ATA).  It follows six artists who will each share a weaving technique on their respective blogs. It Begins on December 23rd with me on www.vancouveryarn.com

Follow along and then come to this Meetup and ask me any questions about what you've learned. On the blog tour each week you will have a chance to win a one-year ATA membership as well as a free submission to Tapestry Unlimited, ATA's 11th international, unjuried, small format exhibition open to both new and seasoned weavers. Learn more and sign up for updates on the tour here (I'll be posting a DIY loom in the next few days,too)

http://www.vancouveryarn.com/blog/announcing-atas-tapestry-unlimited-blog-tour

____________________________________________________

Join us in North Chelsea at Pushcart Coffee for crafting and craft beer. Soft instruction of both knitting and weaving for beginners will be offered by Janna. So, if you're a newbie Janna will be happy to introduce you to the basics or make you more comfortable with what you already know.


Instruction here is really laid back and not structured like an actual class.  For knitting Janna teaches long-tail cast on and basic knitting and purling stitches for beginner projects like fingerless mitts or a garter stitch scarf.  If you're coming with a table-top loom I can show you how to get started or troubleshoot any issues you're facing in a project.

if you're interested learning how to weave at this meetup you can buy a weaving kit at the link below and I will bring it to the meetup. You must purchase it before December 10th so I have time to shop for and make the loom.
<a></a>

http://www.everleatextiles.com/store/p45/PVC_Loom_and_yarn_for_Meetup.com.html

or make a loom for yourself as per here:
<a></a>http://www.vancouveryarn.com/make-a-pvc-tapestry-loom.html

If you're coming your own loom please bring your own weft yarn to weave with. I will bring warp yarn that you can opt to buy for $8.

Pushcart Coffee closes at 8:30pm

PnP would love to see/support your knitting progress at other meetups throughout the month!
results.name: Knitting AND Weaving at Pushcart Coffee with free instruction from Janna Vallee

results.description:
As seen in the CNBC Documentary The Bitcoin Uprising.

Starting at 6:00 p.m. Bitcoin Center NYC welcomes Satoshi Square for a night of spontaneous Bitcoin trading in a LIVE open outcry trading pit. Buy or sell Bitcoins with Satoshi Square and others, or just observe and enjoy a party among fellow Bitcoin enthusiasts. Open bar!

This event is perfect for expert and novice traders as well as exhibitors, vendors, hardware and software developers, educators, students, media, and anyone wanting to be acquainted with the technology. Talk to our experts and get feedback concerning Bitcoin-related startups.

No matter the focus of your Bitcoin interest or your expertise level, you are welcome. Bring a friend who might have read or heard something about Bitcoin. With our assistance he or she will leave with a better understanding and their first electronic or paper wallet. 

All trading is organic, spontaneous, and occurs directly between sellers and buyers. There are no intermediaries, and no fees as we are neither a trading floor nor a brokerage. Drinks and hospitality are courtesy of Bitcoin Center NYC. 

Details follow. See you there!

Every Thursday Night

6:00 p.m. to 9:00 p.m.

Bitcoin Center NYC

25 Cleveland Place

New York, NY 10012

Find Bitcoin Center NYC on Facebook, LinkedIn, Meetup, and Twitter.

All guests of Bitcoin Center NYC are required to sign in.  Media must RSVP using [masked].

results.description:
This page has images of the openings we will be attending, so if you do not see them and you are........


1) viewing this page on the Meetup app click the description tab to view the list of galley openings.  

2) using an Android mobile browser open your browser's settings menu and click ''Request Desktop Site". 

3) using  Apple IOS then click the desktop site button at the bottom of the page. 

For those new to the Hop you might be wondering how you will find the group. Well below is a lovely pictures of myself. Study my face carefully and commit it to memory. Now that I am burned into your hippocampus simply look for me hovering near the entrance to the first gallery.

I very rarely take myself this seriously :)

UPDATE 1/13/2015

Great news!  I will now be easy to spot thanks to a 25 pound piece of marble that crushed the proximal phalanx of my left thumb. Simply look for the guy breaking capsules of Vicoden into his wine while sporting this

Just a little more business...


Every week I receive emails from new members asking if there is a fee to join or attend the Thursday Night Gallery Hop. So rather than answer each email individually I'll kill a whole flock of birds with one stone. 

THE HOP IS, ALWAYS HAS BEEN, AND WILL REMAIN COMPLETELY FREE 

That said if you would like to help offset my organizer fees or buy me a post-hop bourbon you are more than welcome to click the 'chip in' button on the left side of this page. But let me reiterate contributions while appreciated are NOT required. 

And now the openings...

Ran Ortner

Robert Miller Gallery - 524 West 26th Street, Ground Floor  

Jigger Cruz - Smudging Dirty Little Touch

Albertz Benda - 515 West 26th Street

Group Show - like·ness

Albertz Benda - 515 West 26th Street

PM New York Daily:[masked]


Steven Kasher Gallery - 515 West 26th Street, Floor 2 


Louis Draper


Steven Kasher Gallery - 515 West 26th Street, Floor 2 

Alexander Kaletski, Bradley Hart, Leah Yerpe, Micha Patiniott, Nadine Faraj -Winter Tales

 Anna Zorina Gallery - 533 W 23 street


Matthew Craven - QUIET EARTH

Asya Geisberg Gallery - 537B West 23rd Street

Cindy Wright - Glamoured by Decay

De Buck Gallery - 545 West 23rd Street

David Beck  - Alligator Maintenance and Other Esoterica


Allan Stone Projects - 535 W 22nd Street, 3rd Floor

After the openings (around 8 pm) everyone who would like to continue with the group are welcome to join us at a nearby restaurant (location TBD) for refreshments and general merriment.  

Look forward to seeing everyone

Todd

results.description:
Come and meet our community of local real estate investors, build your network, and learn why real estate is IDEAL and why you should be involved with our community of real estate investors. We constantly learn & earn together and have fun together. Within our real estate investing community, we train people with no experience to people who have been working in the real estate field for many years. So it's not important what experience you have! Working with our community, you will learn in depth knowledge of how real estate investing strategies work and you will also develop yourself to be a successful real estate entrepreneur.

At this meeting we talk about the biggest money making opportunities (Wholesaling, Fix and Flips, Buy & Holds, Seller Financed Notes + Tax Liens/Deeds, Multi-Family/Commercial and Money Lending) for a Real Estate Investor in today’s market. You will get to learn about new investors that are investing in real estate and making $10,000-$100,000+ per real estate transaction, we will also talk about how you can make $1,000-$10,000 commissions helping our community grow and you will learn working strategies from professional and practicing Real Estate Investors on how to create wealth through real estate investing.. This way you can learn & earn, get educated so you can invest in real estate, enjoy your life and pass your wealth on to future generations. Because we will cover a LOT of things in a short amount of time such as saving money on taxes, investment opportunities and other ways to make money working with our team, only those who attend the orientation will get invited to private follow up meetings to cover more in depth advanced strategies and working with our community.

To attend, simply RSVP & answer the registration questions for location! If you would like to bring a friend or business partner with you to the meeting, please email us their name, email address and phone number so that we can make sure they are registered for the meeting.

The friendly people at Pride Toastmasters would love to help you improve your public speaking skills, as you boost your leadership and self confidence skills! results.description:
Topic: Intel CPU Architecture Technology Roadmap

Speaker: Charles Milo, Enterprise Technical Specialist, Enterprise Solution Sales, Intel Americas, Inc.

ALL ATTENDEES MUST RSVP directly to Unigroup at  http://www.unigroup.org/unigroup-rsvp.html

• for building security to have you on the guest list

• to help us plan how much food to order from the caterer

• to consolidate all attendees/members


Unigroup is pleased to announce our January 2016 meeting: the latest Intel Processor Architecture Technology Roadmaps, presented by Charles Milo from Intel.

Milo's previous Unigroup presentations have always been well received and well attended. He's an engineer who explains everything from gate level to features, libraries & Linux support. Just ask him anything and you'll get a full, intelligent answer. He's the fellow who got Wall Street firms to use Linux.


There is a lot to learn and know but Milo always puts things in context so it makes sense. The technical content is on par with any technical seminar.

The speaker's bio: Charles Milo is an Enterprise Technical Specialist with Intel Americas. He has been at Intel 15+ years and is a member of Intel Americas Senior Staff. He covers many of the large financial customers in the NYC area and has been responsible for technical presentations & trainings, benchmarking, performance tuning and competitive analysis and software products and solutions that support Intel architectures. He has been deeply involved in understanding customer issues and provides feedback to Intel architects on the next generation Intel processors. Due to his outstanding knowledge of Intel systems, he has received three of the most prestige awards from Intel, Intel's Customer Excellence and Intel's Achievement Award and Intel's Hall of Fame Award.

fees/cost: See the Meeting+Membership Fee Schedule on the web site http://www.unigroup.org/

[please understand that JUST THE CATERING for each meeting costs nearly $400 for the fresh wraps, sandwiches, salads, desserts & beverages. Yes, dinner IS INCLUDED!]

At the end of every meeting a random drawing raffles off items such as technical books and swag. Many new members won a book valued at over $50. That is more than a years' membership!


The full announcement is on our web site http://www.unigroup.org/unigroup-next.html


To REGISTER for this event, you MUST RSVP by using the Unigroup Registration Page: http://www.unigroup.org/unigroup-rsvp.html


Thursday, January 14th, 2016 (** 2rd Thursday ! **)

6:15 PM - 9:30 PM at our regular location:

The Cooper Union School of Engineering <http://www.cooper.edu>;

41 Cooper Square (3rd Ave @ 7th St, bet. 6th & 7th Sts)

East Village, Manhattan, New York City

Meeting Room: 502_CS (** 5th Floor **)


See you at Unigroup!

-Rob Weiner

Unigroup Executive Director

unilist (-a_t-) unigroup.org

http://www.unigroup.org
results.how_to_find_us: follow the signs to room 502_CS (** 5th Floor **)
results.name: Charles Milo presents the Intel CPU Architecture Technology Roadmap!

results.description:
Hello English Improvers!

As this year comes to a close, I’d like to let you know that we will be having the first Meetup of the new year on January 14th.

We will spend some time briefly discussing the American English sound system and then we will focus on and practice a few of the trickiest vowels and consonants for most non-native speakers. The issues of stress and intonation will also be a part of the class. Everyone will have a chance to practice, in a low-key, comfortable environment.

There is only room for 10 in this space, so if you RSVP yes, please make sure you come, and if you have to cancel, let me know as soon as possible, so I can open the space up for someone else.

The Meetup will take place at:

Wine Spring's SOHO ROOM

80 Varick Street, 2nd Floor

New York, NY 10013

Starting at 6:15 PROMPTLY until 7:30.

The fee for the class is $20. Sorry I have to charge, but space is expensive!

results.description:
This is an opportunity to practice Japanese conversation, and discuss and study the grammar, particles, Kanji, and culture. The topic varies among all these, according to what people are interested in talking about and the natural flow of conversation.

Members of all levels are welcome, from absolute beginners on up, and there is never a prerequisite. Native speakers are also encouraged to attend, both to lend their expertise and to receive the benefit of a look at the structure of Japanese from an outside linguistic perspective.

Here's a photo of the area where we meet, for reference:

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

The meeting is free, with no membership dues, hourly costs, or other expenses.

results.description:
The Bi Book Club meets once a month to discuss bi-themed books and the issues they raise. Dinner after nearby-we usually go to Village Den on Greenwich Ave behind the Center. Starting in 2016, we will be meeting on 2nd Thursdays throughout the year.)

The book for our Thurs Jan 14 meeting is the award-winning speculative fiction novel amplifying gender fluidity: Static by L.A. Witt-now on sale at BGSQD!

After two years together, Alex has been dreading the inevitable moment when Damon learns the truth: that Alex is a shifter, part of a small percentage of the population able to switch genders at will. Thanks to a forced implant, though, Alex is suddenly static—unable to shift—and male. Overnight, he’s out to a world that neither understands nor tolerates shifters . . . and to his heterosexual boyfriend.

Damon is stunned to discover his girlfriend is a shifter, and scared to death of the dangers the implant poses to Alex’s health. He refuses to abandon Alex, but what about their relationship? Damon is straight, and with the implant both costly and dangerous to remove, Alex is stuck as a man.

Stripped of half his identity and facing serious physical and social ramifications, Alex needs Damon more than ever, but he doesn’t see how they can get through this.

Especially if he’s static forever.

Next book: The Lunatic, the Lover, and the Poet by Myrlin A. Hermes (Feb 11-2nd Thurs) Shakespeare turned topsy turvy: a clever bisexual mashup between a sexy young Hamlet and characters from the sonnets. Very readable--no olde English. Note: The Sonnets, and Shakespeare, were bisexual.

Deciding Books: We will be voting on what books we want to read next, so check our lists of Bisexual Book Award finalists for some ideas.

Venue: Bureau of General Services Queer Division Bookstore at the LGBT Center, 2nd fl. Rm. 210, phone (646) 457-0859.

Getting Books: We urge you to purchase your print copy at BGSQD and support the only LGBT bookstore in New York City. Especially since they are hosting us in their space! If they are out of stock, put in your special order.

Bi Book Club meets 2nd Thursdays 6:30-8pm. Dinner after nearby-we usually go to Village Den on Greenwich Ave behind the Center.

Fees: Donation to help pay rent

Questions? Email fuscialadybug (at) netzero (dot) com or call[masked]
results.how_to_find_us: Rm. 210-Bureau of General Services: Queer Division Bookstore. 2nd floor.
results.name: Bi Book Club

results.description:
We here at CB2 do not abstain from beer for an entire month! January is the slowest month of the year for bars. Do you really want to leave your friendly neighborhood bartender sad and all alone?? Of course you don't!

Do you feel guilty because of your so called "holiday sins"?? Well did you know that all you have to do is not drink for 3 days in a row and that's enough rest for your liver! Yes, it's true:-)

Besides, who wants to not drink for 30 days?! You're going to regret it and you're going to miss some great beer outings in January like this one!

Oh and besides a solid craft beer list... Draught 55 has food!

Come on out and join us for some good beer & eats!
results.name: Let's Celebrate Anti Dryuary @ Draught 55

results.description:
Happy new year, everyone! Join us for our first 2016 meetup :)

Talks:

A deep dive on the design support library
Igor Brishkoski, Software Engineer at WeWork, will do a deep dive on the design support library: all the new layouts, CoordinatorLayout, Collapsing Toolbar, etc, and custom behaviors for the views.
  The art of debugging
Lisa Neigut, Android Engineer at Electric Objects, will run through types of errors, some fun problems she's had at EO with race conditions, common ways to find problems, tools available to you, and how to read thread dumps.

A big thanks to Igor for coordinating, and WeWork for hosting & refreshments!

results.description:
Setting up the increasingly-popular open-source ELK Stack on AWS might seem like an easy task, but it’s not as straightforward as you might think.

Join us at the AWS Pop-up Loft as Asaf Yigal, Co-Founder and VP Product at Logz.io, will discuss the iterations made to their architecture and some mistakes made in their deployments that have turned out to be common in the industry. Asaf will go through what they did and explain what worked and what failed — and why.

This discussion will cover the following topics:

1) The right architecture for ELK on AWS environment

2) What are the changes required to Elasticsearch, Logstash and Kibana in order to scale

3) How to connect AWS logs like CloudTrail, ELB etc.

4) How can you use ELK to monitor your AWS environment

Light snacks and refreshments will be provided.
results.name: How to set up ELK (Elasticsearch, Logstash and Kibana) on AWS

results.description:
Club Dance Class

guys & girls are welcome!

Would you like to feel confident on the dance floor?

These classes will prepare you for dancing in public!

How it works:

I, unlike other teachers, don't spend entire class on teaching you choreography - you don't need it unless you want to be a professional dancer. My focus is on teaching you how to move comfortably in a club, at a party, wedding, etc. (Unless of course you request choreography).

I teach basics: finding and keeping rhythm, easy steps you can use anytime making sure you know how to transition smoothly between them.

During the first class I assess what it is we need to work on; whether it's musicality, rhythm, coordination, attenuation, groove etc. From that point on, I adjust the class to students' needs.

results.description:
Directions:


The venue is called Brookfield Conference Center. 250 Vesey Street is the main entrance, take the escalator up and we should have a table set up where folks can pick up their passes.

------------

This is the first (rescheduled) Reactive New York meetup! To be held at Bank of America's office in the World Financial Center.


We have two really exciting talks this month, from Typesafe's Duncan DeVore and Petr Zapletal from Cake Solutions 

**NOTE: This is hosted in a secure building, you will need photo id to enter and your meetup name will need to match your id**


Reactive Monitoring with Duncan DeVore

Reactive theory provides us with the means by which we can create modern distributed systems in a palatable way by hiding the complexities of asynchronous boundaries, resilience and elasticity. As a result, we can deliver powerful systems that self-heal and flex under load, but face a new challenge. How do we know our application is working as expected? Why Reactive Monitoring of course!


In this session, we will cover the principles behind Reactive theory and discuss how Reactive Monitoring provides the insight needed for a healthy Reactive application.


About Duncan

Duncan DeVore is co-author of "Reactive Application Development", Senior Software Engineer on the Monitoring team at Typesafe, open source developer and frequent speaker. He has been an avid Scala developer since 2009, holds two patents for software design and led the release of one of the first large-scale Reactive applications in 2012.

----------------------------------------------------------

Distributed Real-Time Stream Processing: Why and How with Petr Zapletal 


In this talk you will discover various state of the art open-source distributed streaming frameworks, their similarities and differences, implementation trade-offs, their intended use-cases and how to choose between them. Petr will focus on the popular frameworks including Spark Streaming, Storm, Samza and Flink. In addition, you will also explore theoretical introduction, common pitfalls, popular architectures and many more. The demand for stream processing is increasing. Immense amounts of data has to be processed fast from a rapidly growing set of disparate data sources. This pushes the limits of traditional data processing infrastructures. These stream-based applications include trading, social networks, Internet of things or system monitoring, are becoming more and more important. A number of powerful, easy-to-use open source platforms have emerged to address this. Petr's goal is to provide comprehensive overview about modern streaming solutions and to help fellow developers with picking the best possible decision for their particular use-case. Join this talk if you are thinking about, implementing or have already deployed streaming solution.


About Petr

Petr is a Software Engineer who specialises in the design and implementation of highly scaleable, reactive and resilient distributed systems. He is a functional programming and open source evangelist and has expertise in the area of big data and machine classification techniques. Petr participates in the whole software delivery lifecycle; from requirement analysis & design, through to maintaining systems in production. During his career Petr has worked for various companies from start-ups, to large international corporations.
results.how_to_find_us: Brookfield Conference Center, 4 World Financial Center, 3rd Floor
results.name: First meetup - Reactive Monitoring and Distributed Streaming

results.description:
Weekly Thursday open figure drawing night at the Shoestring Press!

Models include Burlesque performers, drag kings and queens, SVA and Pratt model alums, dancers, yogis, and more...

6:30-9:30pm, stay afterward for dinner gratis! Every Thursday afternoon we fire up the crockpot and see what comes of it. Bring desert or fruit if you so desire. Beer is in the fridge, coffee is hot (or cold depending on the season) and the camaraderie is warm.

At the Shoestring Press's new digs (we re-opened in February) 663 Classon Ave between Bergen and Dean in Crown Heights.

Members of the Press pay $10, $15 for non-members, or $10 if you bring a friend.

In Writers Workshop, Jersey City Writers' active members review submitted work (ie., short stories, poems, scripts, etc.) in advance. At the meeting, we hone our skills and provide direct feedback to each other in a friendly and supportive environment.

JCW Writers Workshop guidelines for submissions:

• You must sign up for Writers Workshop in advance.

• Keep feedback constructive and positive

results.description:
Are you interested in becoming part of a rapidly growing community of successful local Real Estate investors who are securing the benefits of a once in a life time Buyers market? 

Join our family of Real Estate Investors!

Right here and now we are in a unique Real Estate buyers market which is fueling the rapid growth of our community of investors. With the intermingling of record low mortgage rates and lowered housing prices, our group is slaying in this market. You can look it up, the "world's greatest Investor" Warren Buffet is advising people to invest in real estate. At our investors gathering we discuss not only why, but how there are more millionaires created through real estate than any other industry.

At our local community meeting you will have the opportunity to:

*Network with our local group of successful Real Estate Investors.

*Discuss the biggest money making opportunities in today's market: Lease Options, Fix and Flips, Foreclosures, Seller Financed Notes, Wholesaling, Short Sales, Multi-Family Dwellings and far more.

*Learn how rental properties are one of the best tax redeemable strategies out there.

*Get mentored and coached by the best.

*Learn how to fire your boss within the next six to eight months.

*Find out how you can EARN substantial income while you LEARN Real Estate

Investing.

*And so much more, so bring a note pad and a working pen to take notes with. 

I learned so much in my first meeting and I'm sure you will to. I can't wait to meet you in person, and introduce you to the members of our rapidly growing family of investors. 

So Join us and become part of our family! 

See you soon!

ANSWER ALL OF THE RSVP QUESTION TO GET THE LOCATION TO OUR NEXT MEETING.

results.description:
This is a FREE yoga class that meets from 6:30 to 8:00 pm, instructed by Chia-Ti Chiu, one of the organizers of this Meetup group.

It is an OPEN LEVEL HATHA FLOW class, appropriate for beginners to advanced students.  There are many variations given to accommodate the different levels of yoga experience.


** You will need to bring your own mat.  There are no yoga mats for rent or use. You can buy yoga mats inexpensively at Marshalls, Filene's Basement, Modells, TJ Maxx, and Target. Many yoga studios also carry a wide range of mats for sale.

IF YOU COME FOR THE FIRST TIME: PLEASE FILL OUT THE REGISTRATION FORM AT THE FRONT DESK. RSVPing on Meetup does not count as Beacon registration.  Your participation and registration helps keep the numbers needed for this program to stay free!


FOR EVERYONE: PLEASE SIGN IN AT THE FRONT DESK CLEARLY AND LEGIBLY

DIRECTIONS:The Beacon Center is located in PS 198. It is an elementary school that takes up the whole block; entrance is on 3rd Ave. The exact address is: 1700 Third Avenue, between 95 & 96 St.

BY SUBWAY: 6 train to 96 St. Walk 1 block East on 96 St to Third Ave. Make a right onto Third Ave.

BY BUS: Third Ave Bus - M101, 102, 103 to 96 St.

Madison Ave Bus - M1, M2,M3, or M4 To 96 St.


ANY QUESTIONS? Contact Chia-Ti through Meetup or through her website: www.onelovewellness.com

results.description:
This is a free group for anyone who enjoys playing board games and would like to make new friends while doing so. No previous knowledge of board games is necessary. We're happy to help newcomers along with how to play, as well as how to plan strategies to win the games.  

Our event is every Thursday night at Dave & Buster's in Westbury Long Island from 6:30pm to 10:30pm.  You can leave prior to 10:30pm if you want, also please note that Dave & Buster's closes at Midnight for those who want to stay later. 

This group meets in the Large Dining Room at the table directly in front of the wall with 9 Big Screen TV's.   We are 1 room over from the pool tables.  There is no cover charge to enter Dave & Buster's and plenty of parking is available. Also, there is no fee to join this meetup group. All that management at Dave & Buster's asks is that each person purchase $5 off their menu (it can be 1 appetizer, or 1 dessert, or a few sodas, basically whatever you choose).  

Plenty of board games will be present at this event, but feel free to bring some of your favorites. Some of the games that we play are Five Tribes, Kingsburg, Istanbul, Catan, Pirate's Cove, Ticket to Ride, Carcassonne, Stone Age, Suburbia, Castles of Mad King Ludwig, Love Letter Batman, Lords of Waterdeep, Splendor, The Cave, and more.  

Here is a list of the board games I own on the BGG website: 

https://boardgamegeek.com/collection/user/MarkNY8?own=1&subtype=boardgame&ff=1

Here is a list of Co-Host Kenny's games on BGG: 

https://boardgamegeek.com/collection/user/kenk1982?own=1&subtype=boardgame&ff=1

Looking forward to meeting you. 

Mark
results.how_to_find_us: This group meets in the Large Dining Room at the table directly in front of the wall with 9 Big Screen TV's.   We are 1 room over from the pool tables.
results.name: Thursday Night Board Games at Dave & Busters!

results.description:
I'm loving the momentum of this group and witnessing how folks are improving their language skills and making friends. To me, it makes all of this worth doing!

So let's get ready for another great meetup! 

As always, first introduce yourself in the language you are studying. Then introduce yourself in your native language. 

Following that, we will dedicate 30 minutes towards helping those learning English, then 30 minutes of Chinese. 

Then we mingle again until its time to go. 

We are usually done by 8:30 but those that want to stick around or continue hanging out after the meetup (bubble tea, karaoke, etc) are more than welcome to do so!

Thanks again for your support thus far and let's have many more great meetups! 非常感谢大家的支持！
results.name: Chinese and English Language Exchange

group.name: Queens Chinese and English Language Exchange Meetup

results.description:
The two-hour Cocoa 101 class takes place at 2 chicks with Chocolate in East Brunswick on Thursday Jan 14th at 7 p.m. Let's all meet there at 6:45 p.m. so we can all meet one another. We'll learn about the history of chocolate and how to properly taste it. We'll sample chocolates from around the world and pair them with wine, cider, and port. Also we'll make our own pumpkin-spice truffles to take home. Nonalcoholic cider is available, so children can also participate if you can't find a sitter (they will have to pay). 

There is a groupon discount $29 for 2 people or $49 for 4 people. Here is the link https://www.groupon.com/deals/2-chicks-with-chocolate-4-21?utm_source=google&utm_medium=cpc&utm_campaign=us_dt_sea_ggl_txt_ttt_sr_cbp_ch1_nbr_k*2%20chicks%20with%20chocolate_m*e_d*central-jersey-rtc-root_g*rtc-2-chicks-with-chocolate-4-21-exact_c*110594913548_ap*1t1&gclid=Cj0KEQiAqqO0BRDyo8mkv9y259EBEiQApVQD_SNKZJQHLZNwPCgK0tWv_SxvklPDCujdlE0nZ71X0wEaAkGO8P8HAQ

results.description:
Like our Facebook Page!:

   facebook.com/ManhattanInternationalCoedSoccer

Game description: 

Teams are 4 V 4, no goalies, no gender requirements (but we'd like at least 1 female player per team). Games will be played on a 1st goal rotation basis or 15 minutes time limit. The team that scores first stays on  the field. But if your team remains on the field after scoring 3 goals, we'll split the team up so that everyone has a fair chance to have a great game.

RULES OF THE GAME:

First and most important rule of the game is to have fun and enjoy the time on the field! 

VERY IMPORTANT: 

- NO FOULS

- NO SIDE TACKLING

- NO PUSHING

- NO TELLING OFF

* ZERO TOLERANCE*


By minimizing physical contact, we minimize injuries and violence.


         “Futsal is not a physical but a technical game ”

If you don't sign up for the game, do not show up.

Rough play and offensive language will absolutely not be tolerated!!

We encourage competitive, but safe play. 

We reserve the right to ask anyone to leave who has exhibited any behavior that could be construed as violent, offensive, or dangerous. 

Those that don't comply with these rules, will kindly be asked to leave the field so others can enjoy the game. 


Any other questions regarding the rules of the game or anything else, should be directed to the organizer directly or to the assistant organizer/s!!!

Please check our meetup message board, 10 PM the night before to see what team you are on. This will save us a lot of time on the field.

Location and Directions:

West End Presbyterian Church

165 West 105th Street, New York, NY

Near the lines: 1, 2, 3, B, and C trains.

AS YOU COME IN, TAKE THE STAIRS ON YOUR LEFT AND WALK TO THE 4TH FLOOR.

Call me if you can’t find us - (917)[masked] Manny S.


What to bring with you: 
A positive attitude, pair of sneakers or INDOOR shoes (ONLY), shin guards (recommended) and lots of water.

Fee: 
You will be asked to pay $9.25 dollars when you RSVP. This $9.25 dollars is used to pay for: permits, meetup fees, Amazon fees, Goals, soccer balls etc.

Refund Policy: 


* The Meetup is cancelled

* You can cancel at least 2 day(s) before the Meetup


Very IMPORTANT Due to the location where we will be playing:

We expect everyone to respect the facilities and act accordingly.

Anyone who is asked to leave will not be refunded and WILL be permanently banned from the group

After the game we can go for a quick drink at:

results.description:
Join DM Tom Gilbert in his first Wildpig RPG!

A pale body lays among the dark leaves, the blood long since cooled in the late autumn chill. Frost is forming on the ground, coating the corpse in silver. It shines in the dawn light, while the dark red blood freezes on her neck. In the nearby village of Lyalintsi, Magister Illian Antonov is about to discover his daughter is missing. Another young girl from his community is gone, and he must face his people with no more answers than before. The darkness of the forest is closing in on the village, and the night is full of horrors. The province of Magrevia is a land of dark shadows and deep forests. A century before, the Empire of Thyatis sent its troops, intent on adding the region to its dominion. Today, the Thyatians stay within their outposts, still unable to penetrate the wild lands that surround them. The Magrevian people continue to dwell in the communities that have sheltered them for generations, their doors and windows closed tight each night against the darkness. Maya Antonov is Dead is a campaign for D&D 5E. The focus is on the horror surrounding the players, and the challenge of surviving in a world set against them. Characters will begin at first level, and advancement will be challenging.

Races: Human, Elf, Dwarf, Halfling, Tiefling.
Classes: Barbarian, Bard, Cleric, Druid, Fighter, Paladin, Ranger, Rogue, Warlock, Wizard
results.name: D&D 5E: Maya Antonov is Dead

results.description:
Let's Rob a Bank! 

The Undersiders are a group of teenaged thieves recently formed in the small, crime-infested city of Brockton Bay. Strictly-small-time, though—we’re talking department stores, electronic shops, and a jeweler or two. Two weeks ago, you got your biggest haul yet from a casino job—and got the attention of the local heroes. That part, you could have done without. 

This next job, though, is sweet. Pull this off, and you might not need to do anything for months, if luck falls your way. And since you’ve gotten the heroes attention already, a little rep can’t hurt. 

You’ve been hired by one of the big league players in Brockton Bay —you don’t know which one, but one of the real movers and shakers in the parahuman villain scene. And frankly, you don’t exactly care (or if you do, not enough to ask). The job is simple, if risky—a bank heist, in the middle of the day. 

Tricky, you’d think. Nearly impossible to pull off. But they’re offering you a minimum 25 grand to get it done. Banks usually hold about 20, but here’s what’s better—whatever the take is, your sponsors paying double. Walk away with twenty thou, get 40 from the boss. Walk away with thirty… 

The adult heroes are going to be busy—there’s a meet and greet with the movers and the shakers of Brockton Bay. And the teen heroes are all stuck at school. What could possibly go wrong? 

I have 5 Premade Character Sheets available for this one shot.

Now at the Citigroup Atrium at 53rd and 3rd.
results.name: One Shot Thursdays - Let's Rob a Bank [Marvel Heroic RPG]

results.description:
Comic time! This week: Luna and Pinkie Pie, and Applejack and Rarity  .  So pack your books and come over to this week's meetup for Friends Forever #7 and #8(descriptions and download links below) 

http://vignette1.wikia.nocookie.net/mlp/images/0/06/Friends_Forever_issue_7_cover_A.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20140423141217

Friends Forever #7

At the Golden Oaks Library, Twilight Sparkle and Spike rearrange the books on the shelves when Princess Luna appears. She asks Twilight for help in making the ponies of Canterlot laugh. Luna explains that, after Nightmare Moon was banished, Princess Celestia established "Chuckle-lot," a banquet in Canterlot in which she would perform various acts of comedy and grow closer to her subjects by making them laugh. When Luna returned, Celestia invited her to take part, but ponies still fear her.


Written by: Jeremy Whitley
Artwork by: Tony Fleecs 

Download link: https://www.comixology.com/My-Little-Pony-Friends-Forever-7/digital-comic/121334?ref=c2VhcmNoL2luZGV4L2Rlc2t0b3Avc2xpZGVyTGlzdC9pdGVtU2xpZGVy

http://vignette1.wikia.nocookie.net/mlp/images/0/06/Friends_Forever_issue_8_cover_A.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20140521133446

Friends Forever #8

At Sweet Apple Acres, the Apple Family receives a letter from West Coast Orange family members living in Applewood. They want to incorporate some of the Apples' produce into a new line of desserts. Applejack is excited about the expansion in business, especially since the earnings could rebuild the barn that Big Mcintosh destroyed the day before.


Written by: Katie Cook
Artwork by: Andy Price  

Download link: https://www.comixology.com/My-Little-Pony-Friends-Forever-8/digital-comic/130176?ref=c2VhcmNoL2luZGV4L2Rlc2t0b3Avc2xpZGVyTGlzdC9pdGVtU2xpZGVy

******************************************************

Due to colder weather we will be meeting at the Atrium rather than the usual place in Central Park.

601 Lexington Ave – Btw. 52nd & 53rd Street – Take the 6 train to 51st Street. The building itself is actually connected to the 53rd Street E/M/6 MTA subway station and is one of New York's largest skyscrapers.

results.description:
JOIN US FOR TEACH AND LEARN'S FIRST EVENT IN MANHATTAN!

Join us for conversation and connection with New York’s finest entrepreneurs, biz professionals, startups, hustlers, movers and shakers! Networking should feel natural and we create the space for that to happen. Meet your next business partner, investor, client, mentor, or friend at Teach and Learn. 

How are Teach and Learn Networking Events different?

It’s simple: you’ll have real conversations with people that care about relationship building. Plus it’s fun. Our creative ice breakers and welcoming committee get rid of the awkwardness that makes networking events so gross. 

Be warned – our events get LOUD from the laughter and conversation! 

Who can come? 

That’s easy - do you like sharing your passion, drive, and awesome ideas with other people? If that's a YES, you’re welcome at Teach and Learn. 

Entrepreneurs, startups, people interested in starting their own biz, c-suites, and business professionals love our events. 

What should I bring? 

Business cards, a friend if you’d like, and an open mind. But leave your sales pitch and agenda at home. 

How much does it cost? 

Nada! No gimmicks or hidden agenda. We just want to show you how fun networking can be! RSVP and we’ll see you there.

Our space partner is Bar Works NYC

Midtown's latest and greatest co-working and event space. It isn’t just the architecture that makes a productive work space, it's the people. With an atmosphere that allows you to meet your fellow entrepreneurs, you'll be generating new ideas in no time. Membership includes wifi, copy, fax, meeting rooms, workshops, events, and of course, networking! Right in the heart of Manhattan, 39th, off Fifth Avenue. First time visitors get a free one day pass to try co-working for themselves! Learn about Bar Works NYC.

WANT A BE A SPONSOR OR DO A GIVEAWAY AT THIS EVENT? 

We’d love to share your mission with our members. Let’s talk deets. Email Sam at [masked] for more information.
results.name: Networking Sucks! A Better Biz & Entrepreneur Networking Event

results.description:
!!! Seat Limit: 70 seats (see below for details) !!!

Overview


This night of talks will be on functional programming in Python; how it's done and what can be done. 

Talks

• Functional Programming With Python - Aaron Hall


• Getting Funcy With Python - Lindsey Raymond

• Fun from the Country - James Powell


• Lightning Talks!  See below...

Sponsor

Our hosts for the evening will be Managed by Q. Check them out! https://medium.com/@jbyttow/the-q-approach-to-technology-324b13131ada

Seat Limit

This event has a maximum capacity of 70 seats. Only the first 70 attendees to arrive will be allowed into the event.

Lightning Talks

What's a lightning talk?

A talk that takes less than 5 minutes. A lightning talk can be on any subject that you are interested in. (Please no recruiting or advertising for your company).

Interested in giving a lightning talk? 

If you are interested in giving a lightning talk, please let us know in this event's comment stream. Just post something like "I'd like to give a lightning talk!" and well get in contact with you. If you are selected to give a lightning talk (ie. one of the first 3 people to request to give one), you are guarentted admittance to the event.
results.name: Functional In OO Land

results.description:
Welcome to 2016, everybody!  Since we weren’t able to make it there in December, this month’s Drinks Night is going down at the best little Kiwi bar in Lower Manhattan, Nelson Blue.  Stop in for a chat and a pie and see what Pauli has in his collection of bottles.  The Club will be the ones wearing black and carrying stuffed kiwis (well, some of probably will anyway).

Kiwi Club drinks nights are held every month on the second Thursday of the month (except in December, when we have a Christmas party instead).  Venues vary around the city: if you have a suggestion for a venue, send it to [masked]

Come along from 7 pm to 9 pm and have a drink with some Kiwis. Everyone is welcome, so bring your friends: newcomers to New York and to the Kiwi Club are especially welcome. If you can’t find the Kiwis, ask the bar staff to point us out, and if you’d like us to keep an eye out for you email [masked]

results.description:
We'll meet on the northeast corner of the LIC Sports Field (46th Rd. and 5th St.) at 7:00pm for our 4ish mile loop around LIC. You can run at your own comfortable and totally non-competitive pace and know that we'll never leave you behind. 

We usually head to the pub for beverages and/or snacks afterward - Bring some cash if you would like to participate in our post-run social time. 

For our evening runs, we will wait up to 5 minutes to allow for late-arrivals. Please be prompt.

 As always, if you have any comments, ideas or suggestions, please let us know!

results.description:
The Consulate General of India, New York and the Art of Living Foundation are partnering to bring ‘Meditation Happy Hour’ to the community every other Thursday. A unique opportunity for you to experience stillness in the city that is always ‘on’. Leveraging the ancient techniques of yoga, breath and meditation, the 60 minute session will allow you to go beyond daily mental stresses and help you recharge yourself and tap into greater happiness, purpose, creativity & intuition.

This 60-minute free meditation class is open for people with any or no experience of meditation, yoga or breathing

results.description:
Join 100+ dodgeballers for open gym. The earlier you get there, the more playing time you have, so come as close to 7:00 PM as possible. 

So we are the only sports league that lets people come play every week just to drop in and check it out and play without joining the league.  And hey!  That could be you.  You're a people right?  Excellent.


When you arrive, we'll introduce you around, explain everything, and no experience or athleticism necessary! 

Good times eh? So unless you're a goober, you should probably come check it out, right?  You wouldn't want to be a goober would you?  Would you!?

Any questions, don't hesitate!  We'll get back to you! 

A firm embrace,

The January Comic Book Club poll winner is Bitch Planet Volume 1: Extraordinary Machine by Kelly Sue DeConnick!

Bio: Eisner Award-nominated writer Kelly Sue DeConnick (Pretty Deadly, Captain Marvel) and Valentine De Landro (X-Factor) team up to bring you the premiere volume of Bitch Planet, a deliciously vicious riff on women-in-prison sci-fi exploitation. In a future just a few years down the road in the wrong direction, a woman's failure to comply with her patriarchal overlords will result in exile to the meanest penal planet in the galaxy. When the newest crop of fresh femmes arrive, can they work together to stay alive or will hidden agendas, crooked guards, and the deadliest sport on (or off!) Earth take them to their maker?

Purchase:
Amazon
Barnes & Noble
Comixology

or your local comic book store!

Sorry this is posted so late guys, but hopefully just a couple of weeks will be enough to finish it!

Let's get to know each other over some finely crafted Belgian beer or any kind of beverage (and the food happens to be great as well). I'm open to switching the venue and/or time should popular consensus swing that way. Let's open up our books of Austen's works and perhaps her letters, though we may want to get to her lesser known material in due time. This time, let's talk about what each of us hopes to get out of this Meetup and what we want to shape this discussion to meet our individual needs. I'm very open to what you guys want to do and I'm so eager to meet you and hear what you want to get out of this group!

results.description:
Greetings friends,

This is our annual Bordeaux Tasting - red or white.

But this time you may bring wines from the South West, including Gaillac, Cahors, and Madiran where Tannat is king.

Let's see how they compare.

Bordeaux is in the south west of France, and your wine dealer will be able to direct you to some of their favorites. 

It is also a great food wine. So this is one time where appetizers are important.

You may bring a bottle, an appetizer, +$10 to cover the sparkler, the glass, and the room. 

Or you may bring a complete dish for many + $10 to cover the sparkler, glass, and the room. 

Or bring $20 + an appetizer + $10 for the sparkler, glass, and the room. 

Or spend a lot on appetizers and bring $10 for the sparkler, glass, and the room.

Or you may bring $40 and it's all paid for. Then I'll be able to get some wines that we might not normally be able to. Please list what you'd prefer and what wine you intend to bring so that others can know what other options there are. If you want help me pay for a couple more expensive representations of the region, either RSVP or leave me a text at[masked]-4962. 

We will be tasting a few blind at the end.

Cheers!

results.description:
You're invited to join us for this weekly opportunity to sharpen your drawing skills! This session is open to sketchers of all levels.

What makes our sessions different? 

• We start on time in a large, clean, well-lit space. 

• Sketchers can concentrate because our room is quiet while the model is posing.

• We have coffee and cookies at the long break. 

• We finish on time so you can be headed home at 9:00 p.m sharp! 

• (Latecomers can be seated at a break.)


• This is a two hour drawing session to work from a live (nude) model.  

• We start with short 2 minute poses and work up to a 20 minute pose by the end of the session. We take a 5 minute break every 20 minutes. 


• There are seats for everyone tables and several light weight easels. 


• Access to a sink is available for watercolor artist.

• Bring your own materials (no oil or acrylic paint and no sprays please.)

As always if you have any questions please feel free to email me. I look forward to seeing you there. 

Simon

results.description:
*** 1/14 3D THURSDAY - CES WRAPUP ***


Each year for the past several years, the Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas has been a crucial occasion for 3D printer manufacturers, software developers, and materials manufacturers to get the world excited about the latest product  launches for the upcoming year. 

A few of us who attended CES will share photos and a few brief notes about what we saw there and what we are excited about for the coming year. A few attendees are also bringing sneak peaks of new machines and software launched (the Ultimaker 2 Plus among others). 

For those who missed last week, we went over Simplify3D's excellent guide to recognizing print fails -- and what to do to fix things: read it here!

So .... there has been a lot of fuss about this desktop 3D printing revolution thing for a while now. Still very exciting! 


We have a new-old idea that leaps beyond the news hype and celebrates the wonder of the activity itself. Let's get together every Thursday evening to explore this broad field, in all of its many facets and manifestations. And get to know each other better -- from bold pioneers, to new adopters, from teachers to students, manufacturing experts, to code and electronics hackers. This is your space to grow and share.

Topics we might explore on a typical Thursday evening include:

- 3D design software and techniques. From getting started, to pushing boundaries.

- Explore more of the 3D ecosystem, from making use of 3D printing service bureaus to starting and managing your 3D Hub.

- How to prototype and develop your own physical products, tools, and artwork.

- 3D printing materials: strategies for fabricating in more than just 1-2 plastics.

- Casting and mold-making: from precious metals to candy bars.

- Finishing techniques. Sanding, painting, sealing, melting, deforming, decorating, hydro-printing.... Why just make things that look like plastic?

Let's spend time together sorting out better ways to use these tools, and better ways to design.

results.name: 3D Thursdays!

results.description: Kirtan is a form of devotional chanting whose roots go back over 500 years to India. It is a form of Bhakti Yoga (yoga of devotion) and has the power to open the heart. Musical instruments and rhythmic drumming accompany the singing and the attendees are encouraged to participate by chanting, clapping and dancing. You will not be able to resist the urge to join in! In its heartfelt expression, kirtan can induce profound states of meditation, bliss and ecstasy. There is a sweet sound vibration that permeates through all layers of coverings and makes God dance. That sound vibration is Kirtan. It is a mysterious connection that draws people to each other.

results.description:
No need to write new words - the "Sound Mind" is still a gathering for exploring  vibrational healing for personal meditation, soul expansion, as well as physical well-being. 

We will keep learning how to use our breath and voice for psychosomatic actualization, becoming powerful healers in the process. We can heal our life issues, patterns, past wounds, present woes, and overall life-betrayed-me bitterness. 

The gifts we were born to share come to fruition if we but dare to explore, expand, AND express our vibrational state. You can tune your Soul-Body to higher dimensions and progress your visionary abilities following the scale of sound and color - and CONSCIOUSNESS - starting from who you are at the moment.

The starting point of CHANGE is like that little red circle on a hiking map that says 'you are HERE'. HERE means in your body. CHANGE is a process anchored in the physical reality, where three roads meet - how you think, how you act, and what is your frame of reference, your environment.

Sound Mind gatherings are influenced by "12 Stages of Healing" by Dr. Donald Epstein, DC, "Radical Honesty" by Dr. Brad Blanton, PhD, and the 12 Steps path of addiction recovery.

Karuna will be hosting the meetings - coming from personal experience as well as her practice and training with the above mentioned methods for healing and recovery.

Sound Mind is about a durable and steady progress into who you were meant to become in this amazing moment of opportunity that we call a human life. It goes fast, so why not …make a change?
results.name: Sound Mind - Community for Change and Growth

results.description:
The East River Park track is east of the FDR at East 6th Street. It is a little over a mile from the closest subway stops (6 to Astor Place or L to First Ave).

Thursday workouts change from week to week and will be announced in advance.

Important Information about East River Park Track: The Whippets have been running here for many years and have experienced thefts of our belongings. We will take extra precautions to keep our bags safe, but please avoid bringing valuables -- and it would be safest to run with your wallet on you.

Please be aware that there are limited overhead lights, so it gets a little dark, and during winter months the bathrooms are locked and the water fountains are off. If you have a bike, make sure you have a lock because you'll have to keep your bike outside the track area.

If you feel uncomfortable leaving your personal belongings at the track, you can drop them off at Ace Bar (531 East 5th Street between A and B) -- ask for Justin or Charlo and tell them you run with the team.  They will store our belongings for us.  ***Please note that they will not let you in without your ID so please bring that with you to the track.   http://www.acebar.com/about.html

See you there -- and please contact a Whippet captain if you have any questions!

Satisfy your appetite to meet fun new people with our famous Rotating Group Dinners.  First enjoy casual conversations then you will be randomly seated at the table for our group dinner.  After each course of the meal you will be randomly directed to a new seat!  It is a fun way to meet others in the group as you wind up sitting with different combinations of people throughout the dinner.  It is fun, goofy and very effective at creating great connections.  The restaurant itself is nothing to look at but the food makes up for the lack of atmosphere!  We have hosted dozens of great dinners there.  

The meal will include: Soup, Choice of appetizer, choice of entree, Nan bread, basmati rice, dessert and free flowing wine!

Biryani-Chicken/Lamb/Beef Veg
