Languages of focus Portuguese, English, Chinese (and anything else you speak)


Feel free to speak any language on the face of the earth at any time

IMPORTANT READ ALL DETAILS BELOW

Rules of the Game!


1) RSVP & text name @[masked] to confirm attendance. No RSVP, cannot join. Meet @ corner of Chase Bank, state password.

2) Brief Intro, get to first bar and drink as soon as possible. Learn Portuguese and Chinese phrases

3) Conversation, learn, practice, drink, repeat

4) Move onto next bar with your newfound knowledge

__________________________________________________

SECRET PASSWORD WHEN YOU MEET AT THE CORNER
"I'm here for the language-learning shenanigans"

6:30 pm- 8:00 pm Portuguese @ (american) bar
8:00 pm - 9 pm Any Language @ (irish) Bar
9pm+ @ (surprise) Bar

results.description:
Have you ever hear of sushi pizza? let's go try it out

Sushi pizza is a variant of Japanese sushi served in Canada and the Northeastern US. It uses a slightly crispy yet chewy fried rice patty as the base and is topped with a layer of sliced avocado, a layer of sliced salmon, tuna or crab meat, a drizzle of blended mayonnaise and wasabi powder and is served in wedges. Nori, pickled ginger and roe are sometimes also served as toppings or sides.

Let's go for Japanese this week. 

<a>Payment</a>: Cash Only!

Style : Family Style (Every individual <a>order</a> one favorite dish) We are going to eat Family Style with serving spoon, Do not RSVP if Family style is not for you. we will split the final bill of food . Every individual is responsible to pay their own drinks.

The Cost of Food without <a>Drink</a> should be around $25-$39 per person (could be more or less) . Cash only!

+ Pay for your own drink

Please take your RSVP seriously as other guests often have to be <a>turned</a> away. There will be a $3.00 organization fee for this <a>meetup</a> to be collected at the day of the <a>event</a>.

Yelp Link:

http://www.yelp.com/biz/alpha-fusion-new-york-2

results.description:
If you want to jump start your writing or you need a break from the novel you're working on, come join us. Just bring your own writing devices, I will provide prompts (if you have something you're working on you can work on that instead) and we'll write for 10 minutes straight. This is full- out, non-stop writing. Then we share- only if you want to- and do it again. We usually do this 2 times a meeting. It's a great way to get some words on the page. No prior reading or experience required to attend. You can leave early as we usually do this every half hour. Gotham Writer's Workshop charges $25 for this. Cost of this meetup? Free.

Jessica

<a>[masked]</a>
results.name: Just Write!

results.name: Friday Night Knits

results.description:
Location: IBM Financial District, 33 Maiden Ln, 2nd Fl Room[masked]

Join us the 3rd Friday of each month for networking and coding! 

Socializing starts at 6:30PM — Make new friends, find a study group or study partner, or just practice your people skills. :-) 

Xcoding — That's what it's all about, right? During a typical MeetUp people socialize, work on Stanford assignments, ask other members questions, ask for help with a bug, offer help to others, etc. There is no set agenda and no formal presentation. If you prefer to sit in a corner and code away, you can do that. If you want to walk around offering people a helping hand, you can do that too.

Just Getting Started? Follow these steps . . .

• Stanford CS193P Winter 2015 Class (Swift) — Developing iOS 8 Apps with Swift 

• Stanford CS193P Fall 2013 Class (Objective-C) — Developing iOS 7 Apps for iPhone and iPad 

• Get the homework assignments and lecture code from Stanford University

• Download Xcode from the Mac App Store

• Sign up for a free Developer Account (note: the free account doesn't allow you to install apps on your device, for that you'll need the $99/year account)
results.name: iOS Study Group, 3rd Friday

results.description:
FILM: WOODY ALLEN'S "CRIMES AND MISDEMEANORS" / JANUARY 15, 2016 (FRIDAY) / STONE CREEK - REAR ROOM - 140 E 27th St. (3/Lex),  


6:30 PM HAPPY HOUR / 7:00 PM BOOK CLUB

HOST: DAVID ORENSTEIN, Ph.D

FILM: WOODY ALLEN'S "CRIMES AND MISDEMEANORS"

A great film and lots of Atheist themes. The movie generates the best kind of suspense, because it's about what will happen to people - it's about what decisions they will reach. We habe the same infornation they have. What would we do? How far would we go to protect our happinesss and reputation? How selfish would we be? Is our comfort worth more than another person's life?

----------------------------------

LOCATION: STONE CREEK - REAR ROOM - 140 E 27th St. (3/Lex), REAR ROOM

COST: Free, but purchase drink or food to compensate Emerald Inn for their space

======================

results.description:
It has been a little while since we visited, so I thought it would be a good chance for another opportunity. Hill Country is known for it's Texas style BBQ. From their website:

Hill Country honors the barbecue and live music capital of Texas and takes its "cue" from the legendary meat-markets-turned-barbecue-joints of Central Texas with their distinctive, dry-rub style. All barbecue is cooked fresh daily on premise in our custom meat-smoking room. Our brisket, sausage, ribs and other meats are smoked low and slow over Texas post oak and are served on butcher paper, counter-style by the pound as is traditional in Central Texas.. Updated versions of classic Southern sides and sweets, created by executive chef Elizabeth Karmel, include Longhorn Cheddar Mac & Cheese and Peanut Butter & Jelly Cupcakes. Hill Country features a marketplace full of Lone Star State favorites such as Kreuz Market sausage, Big Red soda, and Blue Bell ice cream. Our bar offers a wide selection of longneck beers, tequila, bourbon, and specialty cocktails as well as live American Roots Music in our legendary Boot Bar most nights of the week.

Here is the menu:
http://www.hillcountrybk.com/assets/file/HCBK_DeliveryMenu_FINAL_4915.pdf

Just in case you have trouble finding the group you can reach me on my cell. [masked]

results.description:
Futsal Pick up games (intermediate to advanced level)

Fee: $10 dollars per player per game; pay through paypal.

Only 10 players per game, no subs. One game is 55-60 minutes. Be early. Every player rotates as a Goalie for 6 minutes, timed it with an electronic scoreboard. We play without a break. Regulation size goals with nets. Futsal ball. Please make sure to bring a white and a red t-shirt, indoor shoes. Games are competitive, but friendly. Please keep in mind that these games are definitely not for the beginners. 

Please no fouls, zero tolerance to this. “Futsal is not a physical but a technical game ”. Minimum physical contact means fewer injuries and no violence. No charging, no displacing with your arms or body to gain the position on the ball. No running into the opponent. Play the ball, not the player. Time it, don’t foul it. 

Refunds will be honored only with a minimum of 24 hour cancelation.  No refunds for late cancelations; no exceptions. 

The school entrance is located on East 109th street between 2nd and 3rd avenues (near 2nd avenue) on the south side of the street. You'll see a row of 5-6 metal doors. Open the door or ring the buzzer (on your right) and someone will open the door for you.

For questions,  use the MEETUP message and notifications tools. 

Post pictures and videos at:

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Futsalacrossamerica?ref=hl

Twitter: https://twitter.com/FutsalAcrossA

Thank you for being part of Futsal Across America.

Enjoy the game!

results.description:
Dangerous Men is out on Amazon and we are going to watch it! Also we will finally watch Birdemic 2.

8 PM - Birdemic 2. The original Birdemic is so slow that I didn't bother to show it at BMN, but this one looks like there is actually stuff going on for most of the movie. Compared to the original it has slightly better sound editing and some gratuitous nekkidness.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Un3Sov5Vxvk

10 PM - Dangerous Men. Made in 1989 but only released today! It's basically an 80s "vengeful woman" movie, except that it makes Samurai Cop look like Tromeo and Juliet. "It makes my eyes bleed... but in a good way" says LA Weekly.


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OWtaV7LXWlA

Please come between 7 and 8. Snacks and drinks appreciated... although I still have a bunch of drinks in my fridge, unless you're too good for anything but Shiner Bock.

Always curious how people make money investing in Stocks and Mutual Funds! Then come be part of this event

This presentation will introduce Mutual Funds, 401K and stocks investment strategies with many real world examples, explaining terms and concepts such as risk management for Growth and Value stocks, IPO’s, Indexes, Economic Indicators, understanding how to use growth ratios to analyze stocks, how to find the best stocks and Mutual Funds, how to evaluate individual companies using Fundamental and Technical Analysis. Strategies for making investment decisions, combining Stocks investments with the likes of Gold, Bonds, Mutual Funds and ETF’s.

Knowing how to invest makes a big difference on how much money you will have when you retire.

Learn how the professionals manage a stocks portfolio with good investing habits to avoid making bad decisions. This presentation will cover 10 of the best stocks recommended by the professional investment magazines.

We will go over how to analyze and compare them against other investments to learn why these companies are good investments.

The presentation will be given by an active investor with over 11 years of experience in serious investing. Please write down your questions and bring them to the event.

results.description: This teaching introduces the ancient Qigong practice of the “Name Chanting Ceremony”. When we call a person’s name we evoke his entire personality. Each person sees us differently according to his soul content. We may say that we see ourselves in the eyes of others. We may also say that the Divine sees us through the eyes of others. When a group of people chants our name collectively, a profound phenomenon of healing occurs. In this workshop we learn to create a group field and once created we use it to heal each other in an ancient ceremony invoking the holiness of one’s name. One by one people take turns in having their name chanted by the group while being in the center of a circle of friends for about 4-5 minutes each. We share the content of the individual experience with each other. Very powerful.About Anton BaraschiAnton Baraschi is a bioenergy specialist, teaching and practicing bioenergy healing (aka medical qigong) in Manhattan, with a focus on integrating multiple bioenergy healing modalities in supporting the work of medical professionals. Bioenergy healing stimulates a person’s own immune system with emphasis on the condition diagnosed by the doctor. Bioenergy healing is considered helpful on alleviating pain, chronic conditions and symptoms without a particular diagnostic, and for spiritual development.
results.name: ANCIENT QIGONG HEALING: NAME CHANTING CEREMONY IN A GROUP SETTING special event

results.description:
So what's a Click event? Ever find yourself looking across the bar and saying, “He’s cute, I wonder if he’s single” or “She seems nice, but maybe she has a boyfriend". Well, wonder no more! Everyone at a Click event is single and looking to meet someone. At every Click event we set up fun ice breakers to get the party going (during which you can win prizes!) You can participate or just relax and mingle at your own pace.

We get it... You want to meet someone special but don't feel like hanging out in bars amongst a bunch of recent college grads or wasting time weeding through online dating profiles. You've been there, done that and want to find your mature match who is tired of all the childish games and ready for something real. Well... our Singles Mixer is the perfect place for you!

Event runs from 6:30-9:30pm

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

$20 for our members - Prepay here https://40sclickmixer.eventbrite.com

$30 at the door if available

All ATWYS members who pay in advance for this event will receive a promo code for $7 off a speeddating event as well as $5 off our Mix & Mingle Happy Hour. Please be sure to check your eventbrite order confirmation for the promo codes to use to redeem your discount.

results.description:
Learn to act while overcoming stage fright. Meet new people and increase your confidence and poise. 10-session program. Scene Work - Improvisation - Monologue Study - Showcase Performance opportunities.

The focus is on relaxation and natural performance based on sound fundamental acting technique. We also provide the unique opportunity to perform before live audiences in our own in-house showcase productions.

Acting programs are often very intimidating. The instructors are harsh and anxiety is not addressed. We offer a more humane and effective alternative. Our program is designed to empower as well as guide you through the acting experience.

Many people who attend our classes have never acted before and just need a supportive environment to try it out. We work in very manageable steps. You will not be asked to do anything you are not comfortable with.

Please do come in and see for yourself, if the program is right for you.

Initial session is free of charge. If you do decide to enroll at the
Free Trial, you will receive a $49.00 discount, and 2 bonus sessions.

Discounted rate:$250 for 12 sessions.

Regular rate: $299 for 10 sessions

results.description:
Mushrooms Demystified with Rob Kancler

"Rob Kancler will be presenting a basic mycology overview where we will get into the biology of fungi, their fundamental ecological roles, culinary, nutrition & medicinal perspectives, mushroom cultivation in the home, farm, forest & laboratory, myco-restoration, a variety of myco-business ventures, and more. We will also discuss our start-up business here in NY which functions as a profitable urban mushroom farm by repurposing various commercial byproducts, and look at various equitable social & financial models that are relevant urban permaculture centered economies.


Rob Kancler is an artist, permaculturalist, consultant & designer, yoga instructor/therapist, and fairly recent NYC resident. Rob is currently focusing on regenerative ecology & bodywork, more specifically food production & security, equitable social & financial systems, and yoga-based therapy."

Rob is a recent graduate of our upcoming Permaculture Designers Certification course in NYC with over 500 graduates... sign up today! www.permaculturenewyork.com


Brooklyn Permaculture Meetup
Every Third Friday at The Commons
7pm-9pm
$5 Suggested donation - no one turned away!

Permaculture is a whole systems design science that is positively changing the way people think and interact with Earth. Turn problems into solutions by joining us in the discussion, design and implementation of projects in and around Brooklyn and the surrounding region. We are looking to create an active group of motivated beings that want to contribute to all the positive change that is happening in our region and the world. This Meetup will be lead by Andrew Faust and occasional visiting friends. Andrew is director at Center for Bioregional Living which since 2007 has been training permaculture designers in NYC and starting June 1st 2012 at their rural campus in Ellenville, NY. A certificate in Permaculture Design is very helpful but not necessary. Click HERE to join Brooklyn Permaculture Meetup.
results.name: Mushrooms Demystified with Rob Kancler @ Brooklyn Permaculture Meetup

results.description:
Happy New Year everyone!!  This meetup always starts the new year with a bang because it's our anniversary! Three years is a long time to keep anything going, much less a boozy NYC meetup! But alas, we have done it, WBEU has reached it's 3 year anniversary!  To celebrate, we shall be going to two places that I hold near and dear to my heart.  The first is Keens.  If this bar was a little bigger it would be my favorite bar in NYC.  But maybe that small, quaint feel is what makes it so special.  Or maybe it's the candle lit, wood paneled walls, or maybe the nude oil panting of Mrs. Keens above the bar, or (more likely) the outrageously awesome scotch menu they have.  We shall start the night here and sip scotch while remembering the not so sober past years.  Once everybody has had their fill, we shall venture a few blocks south to the bar where I had my first ever meetup with this group, good ole Rattle and Hum.  That fateful meetup was only 4 people and I was then only a young Midwestern boy lost in the big city.  This bar features 50 rotating beers on tap so you will definitely be able to find something to drink here.  First timer or returning enthusiast, come on out and celebrate with us!!  

The Logistics:  Keens has two entrances, when looking at keens from the street, the left door is the steak house, the right door is the scotch bar, you can guess which door I'll be behind!  We will meet at Keens around 7 and spend a couple hours sipping on some scotch.  I don't have a set time to move on but it's really whenever people want to switch from scotch to beer.  I will post when we move to Rattle and Hum.  Closest subway stops to Keens are the Herald Sq. BDFM and Penn St. 1,2,3.
results.name: 3 Year Anniversary!

results.description:
Back to France—this time, the southern regions of Burgundy, Mâcon and Beaujolais.

In the diploma program of the Wine & Spirit Education Trust, the most feared unit is Unit 3—innocuously called Light Wines.  This unit covers all the wines of the world that are neither sparkling nor fortified, and it concludes with a two-part exam, essays and blind tasting.  It’s daunting to try to study for this test, since it covers such an immense range of material.  The first time I took the Unit 3 exam, I passed blind tasting with merit, but fell short in the essay part.  I needed to retake it. 

In the essay exam, there is one compulsory question, then you are given a choice of six topics from which you choose four to write essays on.  The second time I took the essay exam, I was torn between two topics—Puglia (the heel of Italy’s boot), and a comparison of Mâcon and Beaujolais.  Given that I’m a rabid Francophile, the latter topic was surely the natural choice for me.  But no, I took a shot at Puglia.  I passed the exam overall, but failed the Puglia question.  This has haunted me ever since.  Why didn’t I write about Mâcon and Beaujolais?  I could have nailed it!  So, better late than never, I’ll do it now. 

Often overlooked in favor of the more prestigious Côte d’Or to the north, Mâcon and Beaujolais are Burgundy’s southernmost areas.  (Although the wines of Beaujolais are so distinctive that it is often considered its own region, entirely separate from Burgundy.)  Both are prolific regions that can offer excellent value in French wine, especially if one is looking for pure, ripe expressions of Chardonnay fruit.

Unlike the densely planted strip of vineyards that make up the Côte d’Or, vineyards in the Mâconnais region are spread out over rolling hillsides, interspersed with other forms of agriculture.  But as in the Cote d’Or, the soils are limestone-based and favorable to Chardonnay.  Ninety percent of Mâconnais wine is white, made in quantities that are three times greater than the white-wine production of the rest of Burgundy combined.   Mâcon enjoys warmer, drier weather than the Cote d’Or, and the Chardonnay fruit ripens earlier.  Much of the production is unoaked, and offers refreshing bright fruit and minerality.  When people tell me they don’t like Chardonnay, I assume they have in mind heavy-handed California oak bombs and often suggest they try a Mâcon. 

One step up from the basic Mâcon appellation is Mâcon-Villages, in which names of particular villages with favorable vineyard sites can be appended to the appellation name.  Other Mâcon appellations include St-Véran, in the southern end of the Mâconnais, where the wines have stone fruit and floral notes with flinty minerality.  The most famous Mâcon appellation is Pouilly-Fuissé, also in the southern Mâconnais, in the shadow of the Solutré and Vergisson crags, which mark the end of Burgundy’s limestone ridge.  Pouilly-Fuissé enjoyed a faddish popularity back in the ‘70s (no, I wasn’t drinking back then), then fell into disfavor in subsequent decades (possibly from overproduction, rising prices, and a decline in quality).  But there are outstanding examples of Pouilly-Fuissé—full bodied with a good balance of acid, fruit, and mineral, with some well-applied oak. 

Small amounts of red Mâcon are made, from Pinot Noir and (more commonly now) Gamay.  These can be hard to find but are worth seeking out.  The examples I’ve tried have had a nice peppery quality along with that bright Gamay fruit. 

We will be trying three Mâcon Chardonnays from three different vintages, which will give us an idea of how well these wines age:  from 2009, a Villages wine from Mâcon-Cruzeille; an old-vines Pouilly-Fuissé from 2011; and another old-vines Chardonnay from prestige producer Thevenet in St-Véran.  Plus a 2014 Mâcon Rouge from Mâcon-Serrières, considered the best appellation for Mâcon Gamay.

Just south of Mâcon is the Beaujolais region, where Burgundian limestone gives way to granite soils, favorable to the Gamay grape.  Beaujolais is synonymous with easy-drinking, low-tannin, fruity reds, meant to be drunk young.  Much is produced through the carbonic maceration method, in which whole, uncrushed grapes are sealed in a tank with CO2, promoting spontaneous fermentation of a brightly fruity, low-tannin wine.  The best Beaujolais comes from the ten cru appellations in the granite hills of northern Beaujolais, where increasingly serious winemaking is taking place.  Cru Beaujolais is vinified with traditional maceration and pressing, often followed by cask aging.  The best examples are ageworthy wines that can compete with Burgundy Pinot Noirs. 

Small amounts of Chardonnay-based Beaujolais Blanc are made, in the northern part of the region that practically overlaps with Mâcon and shares its limestone soil.

We will be trying two cru Beaujolais from Morgon and Fleurie, both made by up-and-coming women winemakers.  Plus a Beaujolais Blanc made by noted winemaker Jean-Paul Brun, using indigenous yeast and low sulfites.

For a tasting featuring fruit-forward whites and low-tannin reds, I thought it would be a good time to try matching wine with Chinese food.  Many thanks to wine-dinner regular Philip for making the arrangements at Land of Plenty on East 58th Street (just down the block from the Townhouse bar).  The fee for this dinner reflects a $50 corkage charge for the table ($5 per person).  Philip has arranged with the restaurant for us to have a prix-fixe menu to be shared family-style around a round table.  Vegetarians will be accommodated, but there will also be pork, beef, lamb, chicken, fish, and shrimp, at a variety of spice levels.  Cost of food will be $30 per person, including tax and tip.  PLEASE NOTE:  The restaurant would like us to pay in cash.

http://www.landofplenty58.com/#!

So maybe the next theme should be Puglia . . .

2009 Domaine Guillot-Broux Mâcon-Cruzille Les Perrières  $33

Not rated.  From the winemaker: “The soil of the Perrières is difficult to work and very fragile. The vineyard was abandoned after the phylloxera epidemic for these very reasons. However, the wine produced is wonderfully lively and very mineral. It needs at least two or three years after being bottled to start hinting at its true colours.  Since 2001, the wine has been aged for 18 months in second or third generation oak barrels without either fining or filtering.”

2011 Olivier Merlin Pouilly Fuissé Clos des Quarts  $45

Wine Advocate 94 – The 2011 Pouilly-Fuissé Clos des Quarts is from the Chartre part of the vineyard immediately above Pouilly-Vinzelles populated by many vines planted way back in 1917. It reveals hints of white truffle and marzipan on the beautifully defined nose that blossoms with aeration. The palate is elegant and refined; not powerful but exuding finesse with hints of white peach and honeycomb on the long finish. Outstanding.

2013 Domaine Thevenet St-Véran Clos de l’Ermitage Vieilles Vignes  $15

Not rated.  From the importer: “This ‘prestige’ cuvée is produced from the oldest vines in a five-hectare parcel exploited entirely as a ‘monopole’ by the Thevenet family.  The average age of the south-facing Chardonnay vines located in Prissé are seventy years old.  This highly concentrated wine of limited production (about 12,000 bottles per year are produced) is aged in cuve (no oak aging).  It displays a powerful constitution with great density; it is marked also by notes of tilleul and jasmine in the bouquet and hints of pear in its flavor.”

2013 Jean-Paul Brun Beaujolais Blanc Terres Dorées  $21

View from the Cellar 89 – “Jean-Paul Brun’s 2013 Beaujolais Blanc is a very pretty example of the vintage and a fine bottle of Chardonnay, as it offers up a soil-driven nose of apple, peach, gentle leesy tones, a lovely base of stony soil, white flowers and a bit of citrus peel. On the palate the wine is deep, full-bodied and complex, with a good core, sound acids, very good focus and balance and a long, classy finish. This is every bit as satisfying as many a top Mâcon and sells for far less, making it a lovely value.”

2013 Domaine Mee Godard Morgon Grand Cras  $30

Not rated.  100% Gamay on southeast colluvium-soil slopes. Vine density of 4,500-5,000 vines/acre, gobelet pruning and an average age of 40 years. Hand-worked viticulture and harvested in small crates. Each parcel was vinified in a concrete tank and aged separately. Winemaking lasted 18 days. Aged in barrels and demi-muids for 11.5 months and in a tank for two and a half months. 2,000 bottles.

2013 Anne Sophie Dubois Fleurie l’Alchimiste  $20

Wine Advocate 91 – The 2013 Fleurie l'Alchimiste was picked by hand, fermented with native yeast, de-stemmed and underwent a three-week cuvaison before aging half in cement and half in barrel for 13 months. There is a purity and playfulness on the nose that is very attractive, offering buoyant red cherries and raspberry fruit. The palate is medium-bodied with ripe red cherry and strawberry fruit and fine precision on the finish. Excellent!  What can be more pleasurable than a fresh, crisp Fleurie, maybe slightly cooled and allowed to warm in your glass. Not much, especially when it comes from talented Anne-Sophie Dubois. She just has the right approach to winemaking – adhering to traditional methods of vinification and allowing her Fleurie to "sing." I tasted two recent releases from Anne-Sophie and, like previous wines, they are a) difficult to pronounce and b) absolutely delicious.

2014 Château de La Greffière Mâcon-Serrières Rouge  $15

Not rated. From the winemaker: Maceration of eight days and then gentle pressing, bottling after malolactic fermentation. Rich purple color; aromas of red fruits; structured wine, light, soft and round. Serrières is reputed to be one of the best towns for producing red Mâcon.  100% Gamay.

Buy Tickets Here

Always curious how people make money investing in Stocks and Mutual Funds! Then come be part of this event

This presentation will introduce Mutual Funds, 401K and stocks investment strategies with many real world examples, explaining terms and concepts such as risk management for Growth and Value stocks, IPO’s, Indexes, Economic Indicators, understanding how to use growth ratios to analyze stocks, how to find the best stocks and Mutual Funds, how to evaluate individual companies using Fundamental and Technical Analysis. Strategies for making investment decisions, combining Stocks investments with the likes of Gold, Bonds, Mutual Funds and ETF’s.

Knowing how to invest makes a big difference on how much money you will have when you retire.

Learn how the professionals manage a stocks portfolio with good investing habits to avoid making bad decisions. This presentation will cover 10 of the best stocks recommended by the professional investment magazines.

We will go over how to analyze and compare them against other investments to learn why these companies are good investments.

The presentation will be given by an active investor with over 11 years of experience in serious investing. Please write down your questions and bring them to the event.

Please get your admission ticket using the following link:

Buy Tickets Here


Event Schedule: 
* A limited amount of complimentary food will be provided during the beginning of the event at 7 PM. 
* 7:00PM: Registration and open networking 
* 7:30PM: Presentation 
* 9:30PM: End of presentation 
* Q&A session 
* more networking, optional. Little food and drinks will be served.

Disclaimer - This is an information session only.
Before you invest you must do research and consult with your Financial Adviser.

Tickets:
$20 when paid early online. 

Please get your admission ticket using the following link:

Buy Tickets Here

results.description:
Get ready to get happier simply by talking about happiness! This is our monthly Happiness and Goodness Happy Hour Meetup.  According to the research, alcohol, when consumed responsibly, can be a great mood enhancer!


Drink specials are from 4pm until 8pm, and we'll begin our meetings at 7pm. Look for our red Meetup sign. Please feel free to arrive late or leave early. It's great if you can RSVP in advance, but in case you can't, come anyway.

As a reminder, this group has two goals. The first is to explore the relationship between happiness and goodness. The second, much more fun, goal is for us to become much happier just by getting together and talking about happiness. The theory behind this second goal comes from a classic psychology study showing that by simply talking regularly about happiness we can become much happier.

While we'll depart from them whenever and however much we may wish, like by talking about gratitude, acts of kindness, meditation and other happiness techniques, the following list of 14 topics will serve as a backdrop for our discussions.

1. Keep busy and be more active
2. Spend more time socializing
3. Be productive at meaningful work
4. Get better organized and plan things out
5. Stop worrying
6. Lower your expectations and aspirations
7. Develop positive, optimistic thinking
8. Become present oriented
9. Develop an outgoing, social personality
10. Work on a healthy personality
11. Be yourself
12. Eliminate negative feelings and problems
13. Close relationships are the number one source of happiness
14. Put happiness as your most important priority.

Here's some background on the research our group is based on.

In 1980 three New Zealand researchers found that after eight 2-hour conversation sessions about happiness over four weeks, their subjects reported a 22 percent increase in their happiness. Continuing their twice-weekly sessions, by the sixteenth week they reported being 42 percent happier.

Our list of topics comes from Fort Myers, Florida psychologist Michael Fordyce's "14 Fundamentals of Happiness." In 1977, Fordyce pioneered the science of happiness-increase with the world's first experiment designed to boost individual happiness.

That's the group, and those are our goals. It's also very, very important that we have fun. With that in mind, let's get ready to get good and happy!


Resources:

For those interested in learning about the major findings from social science research about happiness, and becoming happier, here are links to several excellent peer-reviewed articles that can be downloaded as pdf files for free. (Note: Although these classic articles are somewhat dated, decades of research on happiness reveal that findings on happiness tend to be extremely stable over time.)

Pursuing Happiness: The Architecture of Sustainable Change 
By S Lyubomirsky, KM Sheldon and D Schkade, 2005.  21 pages

In Pursuit of Happiness: Empirical Answers to Philosophical Questions 
By P Kesebir and E Diener, 2008. 9 pages.

Subjective Well-Being: Three Decades of Progress 
By E Diener, EM Suh, RE Lucas and HL Smith, 1999. 27 pages

results.description:
Mushrooms Demystified with Rob Kancler "Rob Kancler will be presenting a basic mycology overview where we will get into the biology of fungi, their fundamental ecological roles, culinary, nutrition & medicinal perspectives, mushroom cultivation in the home, farm, forest & laboratory, myco-restoration, a variety of myco-business ventures, and more. We will also discuss our start-up business here in NY which functions as a profitable urban mushroom farm by repurposing various commercial byproducts, and look at various equitable social & financial models that are relevant urban permaculture centered economies. Rob Kancler is an artist, permaculturalist, consultant & designer, yoga instructor/therapist, and fairly recent NYC resident. Rob is currently focusing on regenerative ecology & bodywork, more specifically food production & security, equitable social & financial systems, and yoga-based therapy."

Rob is a recent graduate of Center for Bioregional Living's Permaculture Design Certification course. Join us Feb 27th for our 22nd NYC PDC! www.permaculturenewyork.com


Brooklyn Permaculture Meetup
Every Third Friday at The Commons
7pm-9pm
$5 Suggested donation - no one turned away!

Permaculture is a whole systems design science that is positively changing the way people think and interact with Earth. Turn problems into solutions by joining us in the discussion, design and implementation of projects in and around Brooklyn and the surrounding region. We are looking to create an active group of motivated beings that want to contribute to all the positive change that is happening in our region and the world. This Meetup will be lead by Andrew Faust and occasional visiting friends. Andrew is director at Center for Bioregional Living which since 2007 has been training permaculture designers in NYC and starting June 1st 2012 at their rural campus in Ellenville, NY. A certificate in Permaculture Design is very helpful but not necessary. Click HERE to join Brooklyn Permaculture Meetup.
results.name: Mushrooms Demystified with Rob Kancler @ Brooklyn Permaculture Meetup

Or just come by explore the space, have a beer with us and see what creations are developing in the MakerBar community.....

Join New York Adventure Club for a behind-the-scenes tour of the Salmagundi Club, one of the country's oldest art organizations housed in a landmarked mid-nineteenth century 5th Avenue brownstone.

Our experience at this historic club will include a special access tour through its three galleries, elegant library, grand parlor, and restaurant & bar with vintage pool tables for its 850 members.

Afterwards, we'll grab some food and drinks in that members-only restaurant + bar!

Rob is a recent graduate of our upcoming Permaculture Designers Certification course in NYC with over 500 graduates... sign up today! www.permaculturenewyork.com

$5 Suggested donation - no one turned away!

Permaculture is a whole systems design science that is positively changing the way people think and interact with Earth. Turn problems into solutions by joining us in the discussion, design and implementation of projects in and around Brooklyn and the surrounding region. We are looking to create an active group of motivated beings that want to contribute to all the positive change that is happening in our region and the world. This Meetup will be lead by Andrew Faust and occasional visiting friends. Andrew is director at Center for Bioregional Living which since 2007 has been training permaculture designers in NYC and starting June 1st 2012 at their rural campus in Ellenville, NY. A certificate in Permaculture Design is very helpful but not necessary. Click HERE to join Brooklyn Permaculture Meetup.
results.name: Mushrooms Demystified with Rob Kancler @ Brooklyn Permaculture Meetup

results.description:
Mt. Mansfield VT / Winter Hike

Приглашаю зайти наивысшую гору Вермонта зимой.

Часть горы, лыжная база.

План маршрута.
Приехать в пятницу вечером.
Суббота -пешеходный день.
Ориентировочное время маршрута 8-10 часов....
Вск. желающие катаются на горных или беговых лыжах, ходят на снегоступах.
Возвращаемся домой.
Ночевка в мотеле.

http://www.summitpost.org/mount-mansfield/150938

You need:

http://files.meetup.com/9125272/Mt_Washington_NH_winter_list.rtf
 - microspikes
- snowshoes
- poles 

- gaiters


  ( snowshoes можно взять напрокат )


Наверху зимой нежарко :-)
Не должно быть никаких открытых участков тела.

Пожалуйста, избегайте хлопковой одежды!

Она впитывает пот, становится холодно.

Лучше пользоваться шерстянными или синтетическими вещами.

--------------------------------------


Directions:

http://www.vtstateparks.com/htm/underhill.htm

Map:

http://www.vtstateparks.com/pdfs/underhilltrails.pdf


------------------------------------

Always curious how people make money investing in Stocks and Mutual Funds! Then come be part of this event

This presentation will introduce Mutual Funds, 401K and stocks investment strategies with many real world examples, explaining terms and concepts such as risk management for Growth and Value stocks, IPO’s, Indexes, Economic Indicators, understanding how to use growth ratios to analyze stocks, how to find the best stocks and Mutual Funds, how to evaluate individual companies using Fundamental and Technical Analysis. Strategies for making investment decisions, combining Stocks investments with the likes of Gold, Bonds, Mutual Funds and ETF’s.

Knowing how to invest makes a big difference on how much money you will have when you retire.

Learn how the professionals manage a stocks portfolio with good investing habits to avoid making bad decisions. This presentation will cover 10 of the best stocks recommended by the professional investment magazines.

We will go over how to analyze and compare them against other investments to learn why these companies are good investments.

The presentation will be given by an active investor with over 11 years of experience in serious investing. Please write down your questions and bring them to the event.

results.description:
Facebook Event page:

Announcing the premiere of the AfroJam Music Conference!

This recurring conference will be held once a year and feature musical acts, panel discussion, and networking. This year's conference will be held on Friday January[masked], at Mist Harlem 46 w 116th street, Harlem. MIST Harlem is a state of the art event space that boasts The Café at MIST, The Bar at MIST Bar, The Terrace at MIST, The Restaurant at MIST and three of the most technologically advanced studios in New York City.

The event features such artists as Wesli, a Haitian-born multi instrumentalist singer-songwriter who conquers the heart of his audience through universal messages of hope, truth and peace. His complex musical arrangements fuse dancehall, reggae, afro beat, kompa, funk, meringue and jazz.


Also on the dock is Anguillan reggae trio British Dependency. This dynamic group of young artists, consisting of Anguilla’s first female bass player, Joyah along with drummer, Jaiden and lead vocalist and guitar player Ishmael, is known for their vintage sound and fresh take on classic reggae styling. 

Awa Sangho from Mali, who got her start as a member of the Les Go De Koteba trio, will also be present at this year's conference. Sangho is a socially-conscious lyricist whose music percolates with the rhythms and resonance of Africa.


Other acts include Nkumu Katalay & The “Life Long Project" Band from the Democratic Republic of Congo. 

Elijah Afolabi (Eli Fola), a Nigerian vocalist, saxophonist, DJ, and music producer.  DJ Slim from Ghana; and Brown Rice Family, a Brooklyn based “world roots band” jamming towards global solidarity and organic happiness. Their sound fuses afrobeat and reggae, rock and hip-hop, funk and Latin rhythms to create a truly enjoyable moment, rocking out in unity.

This event is officially sponsored by The Bedford Stuyvesant Museum of African Art.
results.name: AFROJAM MUSIC CONFERENCE 2016

www.CliftonYogaNJ.com

for more information or you can email through this meetup group or at [masked]. Text or call (email and text are fastest) directly (862) 621-9642.

results.description:
Theocentric humanism is a unique existential phenomenon. It was introduced in its present form by the Reverend Joseph Ben-David, founder and moderator of the Church of Humanism. Established in 1973, COH has a distinct history, with roots in American and European Unitarianism and in advanced philosophy, theology and psychology. While theocentric humanism is organizationally tiny in terms of membership, in principle it embraces vastly diverse populations. 

Come and hear Joseph Ben-David present a definitive look at this distinctive topic. Talk and discussion, followed by socializing and light refreshments. 

This is a program of the Humanist Foundation. Information:[masked]-5662. www.HumanistFoundation.org
results.how_to_find_us: Please use 76th St. entrance (corner Central Park W). The doorman will direct you to our Meetup room.
results.name: Explore the History of God-Centered Humanism

results.description:
Join us @ Rio Bravo for Great Mexican cuisine!!!

At Rio Bravo Tacos and Tequila in Larchmont, formerly The Globe, there's a build-your-own margarita menu and customizable table-side guacamole, in addition to a long menu of Mexican-American standbys like tacos, carnitas and enchiladas.

A good fit for both ladies night and family outings, Rio Bravo's menu is affordable (most entrees cost between $8 and $16) and offers a mix-and-match option so indecisive eaters can choose one item from each section and sample everything.

The space is festive and saturated with color (each wall painted is a different one), and there are Dia de los Muertos statues set in lit alcoves. The sunny street-facing dining room connects to the bar in the back, where there are 55 varieties of tequilas and fun margarita combinations (available in pitchers), like the flaming and salty Torero.

Keep an eye on the restaurant's Facebook page for happy hour and weekday specials, such as Taco Tuesday, Karaoke Thursday and Mariachi Sunday.
results.how_to_find_us: ASK FOR SEATING WITH STACY

results.description:
This is our Asia Business Network monthly meeting. We meet at a location near Grand Central in Midtown Manhattan for business networking. We are joined by English students from Asia, who are either working or studying as professionals in Banking, Business, Economics, and Finance. They are in America learning English and are interested in business relationships with Asians in America.

There are networking activities and a conversation topic is introduced to the group. There is a short lecture and there is discussion on the conversation topic. The conversation topic is always Asian Banking, Business, Economics, or Finance related!  Asian business current events are introduced to the group, and economic issues that are important to Asians in America are discussed. Social networking time is also given.

There is going to be an Asian language exchange and there is English language instruction offered at this event.

At the end of the meeting the group is invited to go to Karaoke, or an Asian club, bar, or pub. The location is usually in China Town or Korea Town.

The number of English students in the meetup is given to the right of the event organizers name as pluses to the meeting. The students include a large number of graduate students from Columbia and NYU.  Erik is the host of the event. Erik has had years of experience in hosting Asian events in New York. Erik is a established member of the Asian community in the area and he improves networking performance by encouraging social networking and giving coaching for relationship building.

Translation Services: There is a Chinese - English translator in the group, whose services are for members in need of them. There is a Vietnamese translator whose services are offered upon request. The group is planning on adding a Japanese - English and Korean - English translator also. Erik the organizer is also familiar with Indonesian and Mongolian. Indonesian and Mongolian translation services are also going to be offered upon request. Translation services are free.

When the monthly attendance for this event exceeds 30, it is going to be made a weekly event.

There is a $5.00 fee for attending this event.

Thank you,
Erik
The Asian Business Network Organizer
results.name: Asia Business Network's Monthly Social!

results.description:
Friday nights under the lights! Teams are 7v7, it's a  60min + game and coed friendly.


Pls aim to arrive early and be ready to start on time. All players must bring a white and black t-shirt. Pass the ball & have fun!


***********************************************************

Details:

1) Teams divide into equal ability - players are welcome to signup with friends.

2) No metal cleats. Turf shoes or molded cleats. Proper Soccer attire only.

3) Played in a fun & chill environment. Rough play, tackles, or sliding are not tolerated. Emphasis on passing over dribbling.


4) If there are no dedicated goalkeepers, players rotate in goal.


5) If you arrive late wait until a break in the game. Inserting players in the middle of the game disrupts the flow- it's not fair to those that arrive on time.

All players must RSVP w/ payment. This goes toward light rentals, field permits, equipment and fees.

CANCELLATIONS/REFUNDS:

If you cannot attend, you'll need to update the RSVP 24 hours before the match, in order to receive a match credit. This is so other members have a chance to take your place.

See you at the pitch!

By joining this group and attending events you agree to the Waiver Of Liability.

We will learn a wide range of Dances and these lessons suited to meet any skill set- whether you are just starting out or a seasoned dancer. 

People of all ages can learn to dance. Students from 18 to 88 have learned to dance in a fun and easy way using the World Famous Arthur Murray® teaching method.

 ARTHUR MURRAY DANCE STUDIOS HAVE BEEN TEACHING THE WORLD TO DANCE FOR OVER 100 YEARS CHANGING LIVES ONE STEP AT A TIME.

Arthur Murray Dance Studio of Ridgewood carries on the 102 year Arthur Murray tradition of excellence in dance instruction. Located in the heart of downtown Ridgewood, their  professional certified dance instructors provide lessons for all levels and goals with enthusiasm, This established dance studio is the best choice when considering dance lessons.- 


Many students have reported- increased flexibility, enhanced strength, better posture, increased self confidence, lowered blood pressure, increased energy and endurance, and a more positive mood. 


DON’T MISS ANOTHER CHANCE TO DANCE!

SINGLES AND COUPLES WELCOME. 

These are HIGHLY SKILLED INSTRUCTORS THEY CAN TEACH ANYONE TO DANCE.! 

BYOB - To This Friday Night Dance Party- BYOB - Wine, Beer- Ginger Ale,  Scotch - Soda Pop 

https://youtu.be/u0lm58cet1g

Please Wear your Comfortable Dancing shoes- 

PREPAYMENT IS A MUST!

 $20.00pp 

Check to Robert Gilligan- PO BOX 184, Ridgewood,NJ 07451 


Or  W paypal.com

to [masked]

If  you use paypal-please send monies as

RSVP Here: http://www.njyp.org/events/winter-fest-party-in-hoboken

Celebrate the winter season on the private terrace at LULU'S in Hoboken! With unsurpassed views of the Manhattan skyline, we will mix and mingle all night.

NJYP-only Drink Specials: $5 All wine
$3 Bud Light, Bud, Amstel Light (HUGE discounts)
$5 house vodka mixed drink special!

Member Cost: $10 online, $16 at the door

Non-Member Cost: $20 online or at the door

Note: Being in the MeetUp group does not make you an NJYP member. You must set up a profile, pay dues, and be approved at <a>www.NJYP.org.</a> If you are not a member, you must select the non-member price or become a member first.


Who can attend: Young professionals, single or married, who are 21-39 years of age.

Tickets: All sales are final (no refunds). A limited number of tickets will be sold. This event is rain or shine.

How to get there: LULU'S is in Hoboken within the W at 225 River St. There is valet parking through the hotel, other parking garages in town, and some street parking, but we highly encourage taking public transportation. LULU'S is very close to the train station (both NJ Transit and the PATH are available), with both methods running frequently on the Friday. How to find the group: We will meet in the private terrace.

Being an anthropologist in your own life and observing your thoughts and behaviors without judgement allows you to discover new possibilities for having love and honesty in your life.  Dishonesty, even about the little things, can get in the way of the experience of love for ourselves and other people.  Join us to explore these topics and discover new possibilities.

results.description:
Open level class. Any level student can practice, taking the postures to a more challenging experience. Beginners are welcome, postures can always be modified to suit the individual. As always, listen to your body, take the postures to were it feels right for you and have fun! This class builds upon Basic  yoga postures, continuing our growth. Students always have the option to take this class where they desire... from a basic level and build foundation or to more challenging postures and flow techniques. It all depends on the individual and what their body needs ! Its an open field  for exploration and discovery.

 Breathing techniques focused upon during practice to connect the body and mind with the breath. Power Yoga builds muscle strength from the core outward, tones the body, creates endurance and stamina. Great for over all health. Breathing techniques calm the mind and ground the self.

There is a 15 minute optional deep relaxation and  guided meditation after class going deeper into chakra balancing.
results.name: Yoga - Open Class

venue.name: Tito Puente Education Complex

results.description:
Futsal Pick up games (intermediate to advanced level)

Fee: $10 dollars per player per game; pay through paypal.

Only 10 players per game, no subs. One game is 55-60 minutes. Be early. Every player rotates as a Goalie for 6 minutes, time it with an electronic scoreboard. We play without a break. Regulation size goals with nets. Futsal ball. Please make sure to bring a white and a red t-shirt, indoor shoes. Games are competitive, but friendly. Please keep in mind that these games are definitely not for the beginners. 

Please no fouls, zero tolerance to this. “Futsal is not a physical but a technical game ”. Minimum physical contact means fewer injuries and no violence. No charging, no 

displacing with your arms or body to gain the position on the ball. No running into the opponent. Play the ball, not the player. Time it, don’t foul it. 

Refunds: Cancel your RSVP ,  24 hours or more before the game and we will make the refund. No refund for late cancelations; no exceptions. 

The school entrance is located on East 109th street between 2nd and 3rd avenues (near 2nd avenue) on the south side of the street. You'll see a row of 5-6 metal doors. Open the door or ring the buzzer (on your right) and someone will open the door for you.

For questions,  use the MEETUP message and notifications tools. 

Post pictures and videos at:

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Futsalacrossamerica?ref=hl

Twitter: https://twitter.com/FutsalAcrossA

Thank you for being part of Futsal Across America.

Enjoy the game!

results.description:
"Injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere." - Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

On Friday, January 15, 2016 Repair the World NYC is hosting an MLK Shabbat Supper at the Picnic House in Prospect Park  to celebrate the legacy of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. through a conversation about the Jewish community as allies to racial justice. Together we’ll explore how we can take action in our local community and #TurnTheTables on injustice.

Our evening will feature two perspectives on the Jewish community as allies; Tynesha McHarris, Senior Consultant at the NoVo Foundation and Rabbi Rachel Timoner, Senior Rabbi at Congregation Beth Elohim. There will also be ample time for conversation.

Dinner will start at 7:45pm and will feature a kosher/vegetarian meal. 

$18 pp, but please contact us if cost is the only obstacle preventing you from attending. 

Nourished by OneTable. Adults only, geared toward 20/30's, People of all backgrounds and faiths are welcome.

RSVP Here
results.name: MLK Shabbat Dinner - Racial Justice

results.description:
Gotham Atheists weekly Drinking With Atheists Friday Night Socials!

Join us for a great night of conversation in relaxed company in New York City. We go from 8pm to around 11pm or so.

Every Friday Night for 8 years we have gathered to enjoy the evening and the company of each other. Every week we meet at someone's apartment, a park, or a bar. DWA (Drinking With Atheists) is for Atheists, agnostics, Skeptics, Philosophers, Humanists, Freethinkers, Brights, secularists, inquiring minds, and all around nice people. No agenda but good light conversations. Great chance to meet new people and make new friends.

See you Friday Night.

Lee

[masked]
results.name: Drinking With Atheists (DWA) Friday Weekly Meetup

results.description:
Okay NYC Fermenters, ready for some culture on top of more culture? We just heard about this monthlong series incorporating Hospitality, Theater and Music. Think kombucha cocktails, a play and a concert, all in a kombucha makers warehouse in Brooklyn. Mombucha is Rich Awn’s artisanal kombucha (a rich fermented tea brew that dates back to the Qin Dynasty) brewed, bottled and labeled by hand at “Magick City,” his commercial brewery located in Greenpoint and site of this Nightcap Riot.

Including a kombucha making workshop, and a take home bottle of the brew, and running from mid January to mid February, this event sounds amazing.

Find out more info and buy tickets ($50 plus a two drink minimum) at the Nightcap Riot site here: http://www.nightcapriot.com/#!blank/fe6iw.
Note that the musicians performing on the scheduled evenings vary. If anyone wants to get together with a bunch of other NYC Fermenters, leave a comment about the date you're getting tickets for and see who can meet up!
results.name: Mombucha with Nightcap Riot - Buy tickets at link in post

meta.description: Searches for recent and upcoming public events hosted by Meetup groups. Its search window  is the past one month through the next three months, and is subject to change. Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you're looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
meta.title: Meetup Open Events v2
